ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FOREIGN VEHICLES ENTERING SINGAPORE

(Emission standards)

     1.  Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (a) how will his Ministry ensure that foreign vehicles entering Singapore on a frequent or daily basis meet the various emission requirements, such as chemical, noise and air pollution,

Column:261

stipulated by LTA;  (b) whether regular inspections of these foreign vehicles for various emission levels are being made; and  (c) will his Ministry also consider issuing Certificates of Road Use for the foreign vehicles that have passed the various emission levels and to require them to undergo annual inspection to renew these Certificates.

     The Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim):  The National Environment Agency (NEA) regulates vehicular emissions under the Environmental Pollution Control (Vehicular Emissions) Regulations. The regulations stipulate the exhaust and noise emission standards for all motor vehicles, including motorcycles.

 

     More than 99% of foreign registered vehicles plying Singapore roads are Malaysian registered vehicles.  They are subject to the same enforcement standard imposed on Singapore smoky vehicles.   NEA works closely with the Land Transport Authority (LTA) to conduct regular enforcement blitzes against smoky and noisy vehicles on our roads.  To ensure that vehicles entering Singapore meet these requirements, NEA deploys enforcement officers to check on smoky vehicles coming through our immigration checkpoints. Vehicles, including foreign-registered vehicles and motorcycles, caught emitting smoke are booked and offered compound fines.  Malaysian-registered heavy vehicles such as lorries that are caught emitting excessive black smoke at the checkpoints are made to undergo a smoke emission test; if they are found to emit black smoke exceeding 70 Hartridge Smoke Units, or HSU, which measures the opacity of smoke emission, they would be turned  back to Malaysia. The HSU has been tightened over the years from 85 in early 1999 to the current standard of 70.      

 

Column: 262

     I am pleased to inform the House that as a result of our enforcement efforts, Malaysian-registered vehicles plying Singapore roads found to emit black smoke have decreased from 16.2% in 1996 to 2.1% in 2004, in spite of more stringent standards imposed.  Malaysian-registered motorcycles found emitting smoke have also decreased from 8.8% in 1996 to 3.0% in 2004. 

 

     On the issue of subjecting foreign vehicles to regular inspections, I would like to clarify that under the United Nations Convention on Road Traffic (Convention), which serves to facilitate cross border traffic, foreign-registered vehicles that have met the technical requirements stipulated in the Convention are allowed entry into Singapore.  There is no requirement for foreign vehicles to be inspected regularly as a condition for entry, and imposing such a requirement would place Singapore in breach of its obligation under the Convention.   

 

     Although we do not require foreign-registered vehicles to undergo annual inspections, the public can rest assured that the NEA will continue to work closely with the LTA to review our enforcement standard periodically and take effective action against smoky and noisy vehicles on our roads.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim (Nominated Member):  Sir, I live in Woodlands and I travel down BKE every morning during the peak hours.  In my car, I can see foreign vehicles - I would not name the country - with noise pollution.  Even in my air-conditioned car, I can hear the loud noise and I can see smoke.  So my question is: what is the frequency of checks during the peak hours?  If I could quote a newspaper today, environmental pollution is "zhai liu zi sun".  We are committing a crime of leaving the price to our future generation.  So I hope NEA and LTA can increase the frequency of checks during the peak hours.

Column:263

Member knows of any vehicle that has violated our pollution control, she can take down the vehicle number and report to NEA and we will definitely check them.  But I want to assure the Member that our enforcement standards at the Immigration Checkpoints are, in fact, very good, based on the figures that I have cited.  But if she knows of any vehicle coming in from foreign countries which emit black smoke, do call the NEA hotline, and we will deal with the problem.

FOREIGN STUDENTS IN PRIMARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOLS

     2.  Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Education whether his Ministry will release data and information on the total number of foreign students in the primary and secondary schools from 2002 to 2004, to let local students and parents better understand the situation and dispel their fear.

     The Minister of State for Education (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (for the Minister for Education):  Sir, there are about 9,000 foreign students in our primary schools and another 9,500 in our secondary

Column: 264

schools.  These make up about 3% and 4.5% respectively of the student enrolment in each of the level.  The proportion of foreign students in both the primary and secondary level has remained steady since 2002, that is, roughly 3% for primary schools and 4.5% for secondary schools.

 

      I would like to say that the Ministry of Education ensures that there are sufficient places in our schools to cater to all Singaporeans and foreign students.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim:  Since we have 3% in primary schools and 4.5% in secondary schools, I would like to ask whether the Minister of State would consider releasing data on the percentage of these foreign students in the top 5% and 10% cohort, in terms of the examination results.

     Mr Chan Soo Sen:  I wonder what is the purpose for doing so.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim:  Among the parents, there is a fear that the students are not doing as well.  So I feel that if we give more information to the parents, they will feel more assured.  It is just like giving the data for the top 5% and 10% of the cohort, how many are foreign students.  It will give an assurance to the parents that their children are doing equally well in the schools.

     Mr Chan Soo Sen:  I want to say that our students are doing equally well.  The foreign students may do a little bit better.  But that is because they are in smaller numbers.  They choose to come here for their own reasons.  So not surprisingly, they do a little bit better.  Even in our top schools, the percentage of foreign students is also well within 5% or thereabout.  The hon. Member mentioned about dispelling the fear.  I do not really see where is the fear to dispel.  My son studies in RI.  This is one of the top schools, and he told me that there were

foreign students.  He said that it was a good thing.  They are very good in Mathematics and Chinese.  We must beat them in order to be Rafflesians.  I said that is very good.  It stimulates competition and, as a result, the academic standards of our schools go up.  It shakes us out of this cocoon of complacency.  So I would like to assure the hon. Member as well as our parents that having some foreign students, who are of good quality, are in fact a good thing for all of us.

Prof. Ong Soh Khim:  Sir, I have a supplementary question and I would like to relate my own personal experience as opposed to his own personal experience.  My niece studies in Woodlands Primary School and she comes back and tells me, "My classmates are foreign students.  But the competition is not fair because the foreign student was originally from Primary 6 in Hong Kong and when she came to Singapore, she was in Primary 3 [the same as my niece]."  To my niece, this foreign student already studied Mathematics, English and everything ---

EMPLOYMENT ACT

(Role of employers in eldercare support)

     3.  Assoc Prof Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Manpower if his Ministry will consider prescribing the role of employers in eldercare support through amendment of the current Employment Act so as to entitle employees, who are caregivers, up to five days of paid eldercare leave per year for the purpose of bringing elderly parents above the age of 70 to clinics or hospitals for routine checks.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Manpower (Mr Hawazi Daipi) (for the Minister for Manpower):  Sir, currently, both the public sector as well as many private sector firms already offer leave entitlements beyond the statutory requirements of annual leave, sick leave, maternity leave and childcare leave.  These include compassionate leave, marriage leave and family care leave.  For instance, in 2004, about 9% of private sector employees  are able to use paid family care leave to look after their parents. 

 

    While I agree with Nominated MP Ong Soh Khim's point that companies could be encouraged to support employees who need to care for their elderly parents, such benefits need not be legislated.  Prescribing such benefits through legislation will impose a fixed standard on all employers regardless of their existing leave structures and benefits policies that they adopt.  This could also increase business costs. The better approach would be to encourage employers to provide eldercare leave and other leave benefits for their employees according to their organisational needs and circumstances.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim:  Can I have the MOS to elaborate more on what are the efforts by the Ministry to encourage employers to provide eldercare leave?

Column:267

     Mr Deputy Speaker:  He is the Senior Parliamentary Secretary.

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  Sir, we are encouraging employers to practise more enlightened HR policy so that they can help the employees to take care of their children as well as their aged parents.  There is a committee which has been formed under MOM that encourages employers to practise more enlightened HR practices and we are working with industry leaders, industry champions as well as industry groups to spread this message of better HR practices because these practices will not only help the employees but also employers and companies to retain and employ good workers.

PROPOSAL TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED RESORTS

     Order read for resumption of debate on Question [18th April 2005],

 

     "That the Proposal to Develop Integrated Resorts be considered by Parliament.". - (Deputy Leader of the House).

 

     Question again proposed.

 

1.43 pm

     Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, like some of my other colleagues in this House, I too had to grapple with the issue of licensed gambling when the idea of building a casino started gaining momentum.  The arguments against casinos may be boiled down to the question of the social harm that gambling brings not only to the individual, but to the society as a whole; particularly the clean and wholesome image that we worked so hard to build for Singapore over the last 40 years.

 

     Indeed, many of us personally know or have heard of families that have met with the tragedy that gambling brings; the most recent being the tragic murder cum

Column:268

suicide involving Simon Lee and his family. The sight of children dying on account of their father's sin is certainly a depressing thing; it drives home the point that uncontrolled gambling carries very high and dreadful social consequences.  If we allow gambling in Singapore, there will be many more Simon Lee tragedies here.  Indeed, the recent study commissioned by the Government estimates that 55,000 people or 2.1% of the population will be at risk of being pathological gamblers.  Although it was said that the percentage of people at risk is comparable to established cities like Macau and Hong Kong, we should note that it is still higher in the comparison.  On a personal front, I was told recently of the sad case of how a Singaporean husband had to write to the management committee of a well-established golf club here to ask for a restraining action to prevent his wife from entering the jackpot room as she was blowing close to $7,000 a month to feed her habit.  And I am sure there are many more examples that colleagues in this House can call on that would clearly demonstrate that gambling can destroy lives.

 

     It is through anecdotes like these at a personal level that we are convinced of the evils of gambling. There are also other reasons why many Singaporeans are against gambling.  In essence, the moralists object to gambling because: (a) it undermines the virtues of hard work; thrift and prudence; (b) it will create more social ills through the rise of syndicated crimes and prostitution;

(c)  it sends the wrong signals to our people that it is acceptable to gamble.

 

     If it was just a pure gaming proposition alone, one would agree that the arguments put forth by the moralists would be difficult to argue against.  However, Sir, we know that the proposal of the Government lies in the promotion of an integrated resort, of which gaming is only one necessary component with which it is

Column:269

used to support the other activities to strengthen the viability of the resort's operation.  Against this backdrop, the issue becomes more complicated.  One would have to balance between the dangers that such a development would pose to those who are indeed vulnerable to being pathological gamblers, and the benefits that the integrated resort would bring to Singapore.

 

     Sir, having cast my net wide to canvass various views and opinions on the issue in recent months, I have come to the view that we can live with the proposition of a gaming establishment as an integral part of a larger undertaking by an investor.  This does not necessarily mean that I have changed my views on gambling which, for personal and religious reasons, I still object to.  Rather, as a people's representative in this House, I cannot ignore the fact that this is a cosmopolitan society with a diverse range of views and beliefs, and it would not be fair for me to foist my own values and belief onto the wider population.  What it finally came down to was to carefully weigh one set of arguments against the other.

 

     The benefits and the economic impact of an integrated resort have been well canvassed by the Prime Minister and members of his Cabinet previously.  That it would be beneficial to Singapore, I believe, is not challenged by the conscientious objectors.  Against these arguments, one would have to look at the counter arguments that are stacked against it.  What are these?

 

     One could argue that gambling undermines thrift and hard work and the family would be at risk if we allowed casinos to be set up here.  Sir, that contention would be true if everyone who

Column:270

steps into the casino suffers the same fate.  However, and with the greatest respect, we know that the reality is far from the assertion placed by the conscientious objectors.  The recent study by MCYS showed that three out of five Singaporeans gambled at least once in the last 12 months and, on the whole, Singaporeans wagered close to $6 billion last year.  Against the knowledge of these statistics, can it be said that Singaporeans have since lost their work ethic and virtues of thrift?  

 

     Sir, the issue, if one looks at it hard, is not about building casinos or providing opportunities for Singaporeans to gamble.  The issue really is about putting the potential pathological gamblers, who make up close to 2.1% of the population, out of harm's way by not having a casino.  As the hon. Minister Vivian Balakrishnan had so rightly pointed out the other day, banning the casino is not the solution as, with the advent of cheap travel and easy mobility, it would not be difficult for Singaporeans bent on gambling to find outlets elsewhere for their vices.  Indeed, with the proliferation of the various betting opportunities, both official and unofficial, it would not be difficult for the weak Singaporean to fall into the pathological gambling trap.  Those of us who have served this country in National Service will know that gambling and betting are the favourite pastimes of servicemen.  The vice is so widespread that the servicemen will bet on almost anything, including the last man to go up the three-tonner.  The point here, I suppose, would be that you do not need a casino to become a pathological gambler.  Opportunities to become one abound everywhere, and anyone who is predisposed towards gambling would have tried out his luck at these opportunities.

 

     Next, the argument that allowing gambling would result in greater social ills.  Again, it would be difficult to see how well-run establishments, like the ones we

Column:271

are contemplating, would be a nest for pimps, illegal moneylenders, and prostitutes.  The Government has given us much assurance that this project will not be carried out if it thought that the crime and safety of Singaporeans would be seriously compromised.

 

     In reality, Sir, we do not live in a sanitised world where we completely keep our citizens out of harm's way.  Our sense of freedom and democracy does not allow us the right to impose our own moral dictates on others.  We want to give our people choices to choose from.  And that includes giving people the right to choose to take that occasional wager.  It is this principle that distinguishes us from dictatorships and religious states.  As a democracy that respects the freedom of the individual, we should always strive to balance our decisions to achieve the maximum good for the maximum number of people.  Policy decisions cannot always be cast in two-dimensional colours.   It would be naive of us to assume that.  In a complex world, what is beneficial to some may be harmful to others.  If we took the moralist argument in this debate to its extreme conclusion, it would mean that we would also have to close down our cruise facilities, as the ships that berth here operate casinos in international waters; we would have to close down our turf club as we know that many a life has been wrecked through betting on horses.  We would also have to ban pubs and KTVs because these are sinful indulgences.  To take it even further, does it mean that we should also ban cars on the roads, since these vehicles are polluting the air and destroying our precious environment?

 

     Sir, the issue here is not about gambling but of excessive gambling.  However, just because there are some in our society who may be exposed to the dangers of excessive gambling, it is not a sufficient reason for us not to have an integrated resort.  The question really is

Column:272

how we minimise the exposure and the dangers to the potential compulsive gamblers when we proceed with the project.  The Government has equally reiterated its concerns and has promised control measures, such as public education, credit restrictions and restraint measures, in some cases to stop pathological gamblers from doing more harm to themselves and their families.  This is very reassuring indeed.

 

     It is for these reasons, therefore, that I have come to support the proposal of an integrated resort even though at a personal level I do not, as I said earlier, support gambling and I have a natural aversion to it.  I have said earlier also that, as a representative of the people, I cannot foist my own personal moral preferences on the wider population, if legitimate individual preferences and rights are to be respected.  I do sincerely hope that the moralists will now close ranks with the Government and proceed to give their full support to the development of the integrated resort.  

 

     Having expressed my own views on this debate, I would now like to turn to the issues of control enunciated by the Minister, as this will be key in minimising the potential harm to some members of the public.

 

     In his Statement, the Minister mentioned that, in addition to the national framework, the Government will put in place certain social safeguards to protect the interest of the public.  These will include measures, such as imposing an entry fee on all citizens and permanent residents, non-extension of credit to residents, no advertising, and exclusion by spouses and family members, and even self imposed exclusion.  Sir, as they say, the devil is in the details.  Ahead of the Government's detailed announcement on these measures, I would like to raise some preliminary issues.

 

Column:273

     Firstly, the question of the entry levy.  I understand that the rationale for the high cost of entry is to remind visitors to the resort that gambling is an expense.  This will keep out a majority of Singaporeans who are either not interested in visiting the complex or find the cost of entry rather prohibitive.  However, at $100, it will not prevent professionals and other high salary earners from entering the resort.  High entry fees would typically require users to wager in bigger amounts to make their visits worthwhile.  It does not make sense for a person who is a regular patron to pay a $100 entry fee to wager only on total bets of $200 to $300.  The bets would of course have to be larger.  If I were a young professional earning $5,000 a month and visited the place on a regular basis, there is a good chance that, with the entry levy, I could end up losing up to more than $500 per visit.  If it was $500, it would be 10% of my salary.  And chances are that that young professional would be occupying a managerial position in the company.  You throw in the managerial decision-making powers, especially over financial matters, and a habit for gambling that, through high entry barriers, bet on bigger amounts, you could possibly end up with more Chia Teck Lengs to come.  That is a real danger.  Rather than leaving it entirely to market forces, can I also suggest that the Government consider restricting the number of times in a month perhaps that a resident or a citizen can visit the casino, and also limit the total amount that a person can bet, based on a percentage of his monthly income?  This would certainly serve as a real circuit breaker for anyone with pathological tendencies to gamble.

 

     Secondly, there is a proposal to allow spouses and family members to exclude persons with gambling problems from entering the casino.  While the objective is laudable, I am not sure if it is a realistic option for many when it is available.  Sir,

Column:274

we are Asians, with an Asian world view of the family.  It would, in our situation, be difficult for a wife or a child to write to the casino to restrain the father from entering one, without hell breaking loose later.  Rather than just leaving it to the family, can I also suggest that leaders of the community, such as the CCC Chairman or even the social workers who are familiar with the family condition, be allowed to put in a restraining order under the circumstances, in order to protect the gambler and his family?  This would help to take the measure one step removed from those involved, thus mitigating the tension within the family.

 

     Thirdly, the Government has said that there will be no extension of credit to residents.  In this regard, casino operators will not be allowed to accept credit cards and post-dated cheques.  We know that the human mind is only limited by its ingenuity.  Will the restriction on credit stop patrons from engaging in a sale-and-lease-back transaction in order to raise money to feed their habit?  Or, for that matter, mortgage their homes?  Who will be the watchdog in such a situation?

 

     Finally, Sir, it has been said that advertising will not be allowed for the casino.  I do not object to the policy.  However, in reality, I wonder how this is going to be implemented.  The casino will be part of the integrated resort.  I cannot imagine that the restriction on advertising will apply equally to the resort.  I am sure it does not and should not.  The question then is, how can we effectively do a media blitz on the resort without indirectly promoting the casino?  How can we encourage, through advertising, wholesome family fun at the resort without at the same time drawing some attention to the casino?  I find this difficult to reconcile.

 

     At the end of the day, this debate is about doing what is right for Singapore, as opposed to personal preferences on

Column:275

moral grounds.  Public policy should not be premised on morality alone, but on the interest of the nation as a whole.  No doubt, there will be some who will unwittingly fall prey to the snare of compulsive gambling.  This unfortunate outcome does not reflect the senseless nature of the policy as it does the senseless nature of one who engages in over indulgence.  Fault does not lie with the instrument, but with the weakness of the human character who uses the instrument. 

 

     With this, Sir, I would like to urge the nation now to rally behind the Government in giving its full support to the proposal of the integrated resort.

     The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in this discussion.

 

     Sir, the MM has spoken, and with such force, and we all know it is not easy to disagree with the Minister Mentor.  But I think MM will also be one person who will agree that concerns remain and it will be very difficult actually to convince those who disagree with the idea of having casinos or IRs.  But this is not a small number, and we have to find a way to make sure that we will not end up dividing our Singapore society.  When MM speaks, many listen, not only in Singapore, the region, but all over the world.  And MM asked what signals are we sending to the world, to investors and non-investors alike.  But I would also like to ask what signals do we understand from this discussion?  Do we really understand the signals which I think the Government is sending to us Singaporeans about the change that has taken place, about the challenges, the elements of competition, with emerging China and India, and what other opportunities and options do we have to make Singapore to continue to succeed and prosper?

 

Column:276

     I think our discussion is also drawing a lot of attention across the causeway in Malaysia.  Many Malaysian media, newspapers, television stations, even leaders, have responded to this.  Many are positive, some negative, some even cynical.  And for those who are positive, they agree that the IRs will be good for tourism in the region.  I was told that even the Chairman of the tourism board and the Secretary-General of the Tourism Ministry was quoted on CNA last night about growing the regional tourism pie, and I am sure this is in fact the reason the Singapore Government has opted for this approach to IRs, and this is in fact our hope too. 

 

     Let me quote the Secretary-General of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr Ng Yeow Song, who said that the Singapore Government was probably keeping up with the current trend to attract more tourists to the republic.  He said, in fact, Johor could also benefit from it if Johor were to protect its environment, ie, it would raise the state's tourism potential.  Also, the President of the Malaysian Chinese Tourism Association, Mr Chay Ng, felt that the impact of Singapore IRs

on Malaysia would be insignificant.  Instead, it would probably boost Malaysia's tourist industry.  He said tour operators should view the matter with foresight and should not be close-minded.  To quote him, "Tour operators, including the Tourism Ministry need not worry about the issue but should instead face it with an open mind."  So I would also like to urge our Singaporeans to approach this issue of IRs with an open mind. 

 

     But let me say at the outset that, as a Muslim, my position has to be no for religious considerations.  But I am troubled in the sense that I live in an environment where it is a secular society, it is multi-racial and multi-religious.  Can one community dictate the needs and decisions of the others, as Minister Yaacob Ibrahim has said on Monday?  I think we have to

Column:277

be pragmatic, realistic and rational in our approach towards this issue.

 

     I am also troubled in the sense that when I look around the world, I do see quite a number of Muslim countries - Malaysia, Cairo, Morocco - have casinos.  But, at the same time, I do not see them coming out of a situation, becoming so immoral as a society, so degrading as a society.  They also use that as a tool to attract tourists to their countries.  I think many of us also realise that, in fact, some of the best gamblers, if you like, those who patronise casinos all over the world, are Muslims.  They may be good customers to the casinos but bad examples or models for the Muslim community.

 

     Sir, for sure, we Singaporeans have been proud of our safe, clean and green image. That is something worth fighting for to upkeep. The question now is whether we are going to soil our image and go amber with IRs, what with the casinos thrown in.  Risks are there for sure, especially the understandable concerns regarding the increased social ills, or even increase in crimes related to gambling.  Clearly,  some Singaporeans who are sincerely opposed to having casinos in Singapore will be disappointed and they might even say that there is no point in discussing the issue anymore as it looks like 'head I win, tail you lose' for the Government.  But to these fellow Singaporeans, Muslims and non-Muslims alike, I appeal to them to keep their minds open and see how the decision on IRs could be turned into a win-win situation for Singapore.  Rest assured that judging from PM and Ministers' speeches and assurances, those concerns expressed have not completely fallen on deaf ears.

 

     Sir, undoubtedly, the decision to go IRs was not an easy one for Singapore. It took Singapore 40 years to do so. Surely, when we became independent, with so

Column:278

scarce natural resources, a casino would have been an easy choice. After all, Singapore was and is at the geographical crossroads of Asia. It would have been a convenient oasis for one.  But no, Singapore, thanks to our pioneering leaders of independent Singapore, Mr Lee Kuan Yew and his strong views, in particular, avoided that option. Be it industrialisation, import substitution, export promotion, assembly of components, simple manufacturing, high technology, life sciences, financial  services and developing Singapore as medical and educational hubs, we have been there. Why then now? In many eyes, this is a drastic change in position as far as casinos are concerned.

 

     Is the economy that bad?   Are we throwing in the towels with competition through the tested ways? Are we lost on ideas to fight competition from China and India and other emerging economies?  Or indeed,  are the IRs our new additional tool to meet those challenges? I believe the latter is the reason why our Government has chosen to do so. We need all hands on deck and all tools possible to meet the new challenges of  globalisation and the new wave of competition confronting us. It is a new world that demands a new and creative approach to meet them.

 

     Obviously, I am not saying, at all costs, especially the social costs, which many Singaporeans are justly concerned about.  However, I trust most Singaporeans will be reassured by the approach taken by Government in tackling the issue.  We have heard the assurance given by the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Wong Kan Seng, who himself had shared with us his concerns and what measures his Ministry will embark upon to tackle the crime angle.  The package announced by Minister Vivian Balakrishnan to work with FSCs and community organisations will also help.  To those who believe that the Government should not throw the problem arising from gambling to the community,

Column:279

they should ask themselves whether in fact that is the right attitude.  We face the challenges of making Singapore to continue to succeed and prosper together and we can and should handle the fallouts, if any, together too.


     To quote a friend, Mr Ahmad Isa Rahim, "After hearing PM and the other Ministers spoke, especially Mr Wong Kan Seng, I am convinced that the Government is sincere in tackling the social cost for the IRs." He said it was  a good start.  He, like many other Muslim Singaporeans, and many other Singaporeans too, eg, Catholics and those who do not profess a religion, are also against it.  But he is willing to accept why the Government had to make that decision, as long as we are prepared to tackle the problems that might arise.

 

     The sincerity is very clear.  Here in Singapore, it is not a case of us going for IRs because we want to benefit a certain group or certain individuals with the kind of opportunities for development of the casinos.  Here, I think the basic principle with which the Government has approached this issue is how do we use IRs to the advantage of Singaporeans and Singapore in general.  That is for the benefit of all.  But having said that, we recognise the problems that might arise.  We accept the concerns which many Singaporeans have raised and we should tackle them collectively.

 

     Clearly, many Muslims will also be opposed to it but I believe that most Muslim Singaporeans would be able to understand that this is part of the reality of living in a plural and secular society.

 

     I am also confident that Muslim Singaporeans, even if they are against the idea, would understand the thinking behind Government's move and not confuse the casino issue with the IRs. I know they are inter-related, but while Muslims should choose not to work at the

Column:280

casinos, they should not deny themselves the job opportunities that will be created through the wider concept of IRs.

 

     Personally, I believe that if I expect others to respect my faith, it is morally and spiritually right for me to give my neighbours and friends, who do not see it as wrong to have casinos in Singapore and IRs in general, the respect and space for them to live life as they chose.

 

     Having said that, we should not take lightly the differences that have emerged over the issue.  Many Singaporeans, I believe, will be reassured by the approach taken by the PM to reach out to community and religious organisations to explain further the Government decision and to encourage them to work together with the Government in tackling the issue and the problems that might arise.

 

    We must not allow the decision to go IRs divide the society.  The painstaking efforts we have taken  to make Singapore a more cohesive society should not be put at risk because of this issue.  I would also like to urge community and religious organisations to respond positively to PM's call and work together for the common benefit of our Singapore. This is a win-win formula we cannot afford to lose.   We must work together, whatever the challenges.  Make this a "Uniquely Singapore" experiment.  We have experimented with many ideas and projects which others even shudder to think about - some very controversial policies which we have initiated and followed on earlier on in our independence but proven to be right later on.  But with the need for us to constantly watch what are the challenges and demands in terms of fine-tuning and adjustments that are required to make sure that our initial objective of the good for Singapore is not lost.  

 

    Let this work too, not only in terms of material gains but also in our managing its social costs.

Column:281

     Dr Warren Lee (Sembawang): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak in favour of the integrated resorts. 

 

     People who know me as a Christian MP may well wonder why I take this stand.  I am well aware that many thoughtful Singaporeans of all faiths and creeds have expressed their strong reservations about letting in the evils of casinos on our own land.  Many have tried to persuade me to take a stand against the casinos and were disappointed when I did not.  And I made my support for the IRs known to PM Lee sometime ago.

 

     As a pragmatic Christian MP, representing multi-racial and multi-religious constituency in a secular state, I join PM and his Cabinet colleagues and fellow MPs in stating that my stand is taken with a heavy heart and with full recognition of the potential downsides that the integrated resorts and associated casinos may bring.  In the end, it is because I feel that the upsides outweigh the downsides and it is because I feel that we are better off, confronting and dealing with the phenomenon of problem gambling, rather than trying to prohibit all gambling and pretending that we are too nice a place for all these nasty things to happen.

 

     Like many others in this House, I have had the subject weighing upon my conscience and my thoughts for many months.  I am personally against gambling.  I do not gamble and have never as much as bought a Singapore Big Sweep ticket, Toto or 4-D.  Like many other Singaporeans, I do take part in lucky draw promotions and support worthy causes with donation draws.  But aside from that, no gambling for me.

 

     I have seen the effects of gambling.  I grew up in the Bukit Timah area and for many years endured the weekly traffic jams outside the old Turf Club, with its stream of people coming out after the races - the winners in cabs and cars; the

Column: 282

losers in buses or walking home. After the races, few would look happy.  Mostly, the faces looked dejected.  But they came week after week and I resolved never to join them.

 

     Later, during my NS days in the SAF's drug abuse rehabilitation unit, I met soldiers who had gone AWOL to pay their own or their wives' gambling debts.  I realised then that gambling could be an addiction, just like drugs.  Later, I got to know residents, friends and colleagues with many sad stories to tell.  Someone whose father gambled away their five-room flat; many others educated and not so well-educated who gambled away their businesses; and another whose husband started gambling soon after she became pregnant with their first child and later wrecked their marriage. Residents who came to me with stories of harassment by loan sharks, people forced to put their wives and girlfriends into prostitution to pay their gambling debts.  I have heard of a respectable retiree teacher who gambled away $400,000 of retirement gratuity on cruise ship casinos.  I have heard of housewives who crammed the 3.30 pm ferry back from Batam to Singapore, getting home just in time to cook for their husbands, having gambled away up to $500 in a day in the casinos in our neighbouring islands. 

 

     I know that casinos will bring birds of prey, people who will be looking out for those running short of money - foreign students getting a taste of freedom, call girls and so on.

I hope that Singapore's IRs, when they do come up, will address those questions squarely.  Perhaps we should have our plain-clothes policemen looking out for these birds of prey and tackling them as they would tackle organised crime and drug-traffickers. 

 

     Yes, there is an undeniable downside, if we were to bring in the casino.  Yes, gambling can be a dehumanising addiction

Column:283

that drives people to do desperate and silly things to feed their addiction.  Yet, we must see the bigger picture.  What would happen if we did not have an integrated resort-type development?  What would it take to bring in world-class attractions that would revitalise Singapore as a buzzing place to be? 

 

     As a practising pediatrician and diabetes specialist, I often travel overseas to give medical talks and attend medical conventions.  I know that what we have in Singapore pales in comparison to many convention centres and facilities abroad.  Singapore's largest convention facility can perhaps take in 12,000 people, with 5,000 rooms within so-called walking distance.  This sounds very impressive until you know of other places that can take in 18,000-20,000 people for scientific or professional conventions and trade exhibitions and still have room for many more and hotels, food outlets and entertainment nearby to accommodate people on all sorts of budgets and with all sorts of requirements.  

 

     When you realise that these convention centres are often fully booked year round, you realise why the MICE (Meetings, Incentives, Conventions and Exhibitions) business is central to the economies of so many so-called second-tier American cities likes Las Vegas, Atlanta, Orlando, San Francisco, New Orleans, and so on.  Such events can bring millions into the economy in the space of a few days, with spillover effects for all sorts of ancillary services and businesses, but only if the meetings actually come to town year after year.  Yes, we have Changi and the Singapore Expo with their huge halls, but they are far away from the hotel belt and you would need to take the bus or MRT there.  And the parking system, as many have found, is not always ideal.  In fact, if you hold a meeting in the Suntec or Raffles City belt, you may find that delegates are unwilling even to put up in an Orchard Road belt hotel.

 

Column: 284

     Singapore has been touted as a top MICE destination in the last decade, but I think it would not even make it to the shortlist of mega venues for large events.  The competition is hotting up as regional cities realise the potential of such business and gear up their facilities.  Ms Ong Sor Chin, writing in the Straits Times, wondered whether having two IRs would adversely affect the business of our existing convention facilities.  I think not.  Smaller meetings would still benefit from the entertainment options that the two large IRs would bring and the added traffic would add buzz we so sorely need, and increasingly lack.  Should a mega meeting come to town, numerous satellite meetings would need all the break-out rooms and hotel rooms we can muster in the downtown region.  Remember, Macau is already planning an IR with 10,000 rooms on-site.  Conventions for professionals are not like air shows and trade exhibitions.  People need to be able to go from their hotels to the lecture theatres in the shortest time possible, while their partners and families get to do something interesting, or go shopping, and then have the whole group come together for a meal or entertainment at the end of the day.  These attendees need to be able to mix business and pleasure at the same place.  Most would like to dine, wine, shop, be entertained and then often bring home presents for their wives and kids because they feel a little guilty about having had such a good time.  If we play it right, they would resolve to bring their family on the next trip, if they had a good and safe time.  

 

     In many convention centres with casinos, a visitor would be hard-pressed to tell you where the casino was.  But I think that sufficient numbers would visit, have a flutter and patronise the casino to make the cross-subsidies viable enough to support the total complex.  As PM Lee had said, the numbers only seem to work out when you have a casino as part of an IR.  I would urge the Government, however,

Column:285

to ensure that in evaluating the plans for the IR, that we actually make sure that the convention facilities are not tagged on as an after-thought, but really with the idea in mind of making sure that we become a serious mega venue for future conferences because you need the scale,  human traffic, investments, classy shows and top-class museum exhibits to keep people coming back for more, year after year.  Then you also need to keep upgrading and improving the facilities every five or 10 years.  This then is why I think we have no choice but to build the integrated resorts.  We sorely need the next generation of large convention and tourist facilities to attract the MICE business and remain an attractive destination for people, pleasure, planes and ships to visit.  And, then we have to manage the downside.  

 

     I share Dr Tan Sze Wee's concern that studies have shown that legalised gambling seems to increase the number of social and medical ills.  We are all rightly concerned about the 1%, 2% or 3%, maybe more, who will manifest gambling addiction, and so on.  Dr Tan has asked whether one more family wrecked by gambling is worth all the money to be made.  It is a serious thought.  Yet, as a PAP MP, I know as many of my colleagues in this House know, that families are also wrecked by wage-earners losing their jobs and having no employment to turn to.  I know that many have turned to gambling when they lose their jobs or when their businesses have gone downhill in an economic downturn.  I know that moral and financial ruin can also come from irresponsible hire purchase decisions, ill-advised renovation loans and the pursuit of branded consumer goods and fashion accessories.  So while statistics may show that gamblers may manifest more spousal violence, child abuse and so on, I know full well that these ills also increase markedly during an

Column:286

economic downturn.  To be fair, we need to dig deeper into many of these statistics to determine conciliaty or, to put it simply, which is the chicken and which is the egg.  The prospect of 35,000 jobs, a more vibrant tourist destination, more jobs for retail, F&B, transport and hospitality industries, a more attractive reason to be an air hub, a more lively city for an international workforce, more attractiveness as a commercial hub, these are very strong arguments.  I would have to ask Dr Tan and many of my friends how many families must go hungry while we maintain our moral high ground.

 

     Yet I agree that we need to do more for the people who may be affected by this.  We need to nip the problem in the bud the moment someone manifests behaviour that suggests that for him or her gambling has gone beyond responsible entertainment to destructive behaviour. 

 

     To me, a key measure is the availability of the option to bar oneself or to bar a family member from the IRs, if he or she is at risk.  We should perhaps extend this to all forms of gambling and also make this remedy available to medical professionals and community leaders, aware of, and responsible for a person with a gambling addiction.  One woman whose ex-husband was a compulsive gambler asked me the obvious question:  if I had barred my husband, would my husband have known who barred him?  Would it not, as Mr Sin Boon Ann has also pointed out, cause all sorts of havoc at home?  This is a real problem, given that many of these compulsive gamblers actually are already prone to spousal violence.  So we have to think of a mechanism.  Perhaps to say that only the spouse or children have the authority to do so and reveal who these people are may not be the best way.  We should be aware that gambling is pre-existent and pervasive in our society and increasingly accessible via the Internet and easy travel options even at this time with no casino in Singapore.  I

Column: 287

think recent stories in the papers have borne this out.  Hence, we need to emphasise parental advice and example. 

 

     Perhaps we can draw a lesson from others.  Many years ago, when I visited my cousins in Hong Kong, I realised that the news-stands in their rather upmarket residential area sold pornography quite openly and I asked my aunt how she protected her children from these influences.  What she said then, 20 years ago, struck me.  She said, "I tell my children, well, this is the way that other people may do things.  But this is not the way our family does things."  She recognised and confronted the issue and made sure that her children knew right from wrong.  They are very successful now, by the way.  

 

     However, there will always be people who become problem gamblers and they leave a trail of destruction behind them.  How do we protect their family members?  We should perhaps pass legislation to protect CPF balances for the non-gambling spouse so that we prevent people from gambling away their retirement funds.  It is difficult, but we should find a way to do this because I know that in Australia, one of the big problems is the elderly and retired gambling away their savings.  I am heartened to know that ATM withdrawal limits and cash-only terms are measures being considered.  But we really should go after the loan-sharks who prey in these casinos. 

 

     We need to maintain our squeaky-clean and wholesome image in spite of the decision of casinos in our IRs.  We can also perhaps make barring or gambling limits available to not just our own citizens, but hotel guests and their families.  This would enhance the image of Singapore as a place where you could safely have a flutter but not lose your shirt.  We need to strongly go after all forms of loan-shark activity and treat it as organised crime, so that loan- sharking

Column: 288

becomes a very unattractive profession, just like drug trafficking, because both deal in human misery.  We need to protect our womenfolk, perhaps, with new legislation to make sure they are not unwitting victims.  We need to have organisations who have made known their opposition to the casinos to come forward and help those Singaporeans avoid and escape all forms of gambling - casino, lottery or otherwise.  We need to adequately fund and build up services for those with gambling addiction and perhaps consider treating the worst cases in residential rehabilitation centres, like DRC.  I think this can help with both casino and non-casino gambling.  In this respect, Mr Deputy Speaker's suggestion yesterday that perhaps some of the taxes should go directly to fund these services, I think, is a laudable one.

 

     I think we need to ensure that winners can bank in their winnings safely, go home safely and live to become loyal repeat customers.  We should not let crime rise outside the casino.  We need to keep the underworld at bay.  We also need to consider the role of junket operators, online gambling and cruise ship casinos in encouraging gambling among Singaporeans who have been kept out, one way or the other, from our own IRs.  How do we stop these people from targeting our Singaporeans?  We need to be equally concerned about foreign visitors to ensure that, for them, a visit to a Singapore casino will not turn into a financial disaster but a pleasant, if expensive, bit of entertainment.  And finally, as parents, we need to show good personal examples to our children.  Do we gamble at all?  On or off the golf-course?  Do we buy 4-D, Toto?  Do we allow Internet gambling in our homes?  Do we play video poker?  Do we allow people to go for 4-D so easily?  In fact, some of the people currently affected by gambling, spouses have said they would wish that the Government had a way to control these people.  

 

Column: 289

     Finally, when I started asking people about the effects of the resorts, one elderly person said, "Look, look, look, don't talk about that.  Where are the 35, 000 jobs?  I want to be in line for one of them."  So this issue has to be seen in its totality and not just on moral grounds.

 

     On this note, Sir, I support the IRs.

     Dr Geh Min (Nominated Member): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in this debate.

 

     Singaporeans are divided on the issue of the casino - whether to have it or not.  It is quite clear that the House, too, is divided on this issue.  I think many of us are divided within ourselves.  We are persuaded on some reasons and grounds and we are against it on other grounds.  But, there is one aspect of this issue where we are all united.  I think I can confidently say this both inside and outside the House and, that is, in deploring the effects of gambling on individuals, families and communities.  We are, therefore, also united in wanting to minimise these effects.

I am somewhat reassured by what was said by the Ministers for Home Affairs, Community Development, Youth and Sports, and Health on the precautions and safety nets that will be put in place.  I think we all agree that we cannot have too many safety nets, the more the better.  We also, I believe, need an independent body to check on these safety nets, whether they are placed where they should be, whether they are working effectively, and whether they are sufficient.

 

     I should therefore like to urge the Government to initiate an establishment of an independent gambling tribunal.  It should have multi-agency representation, both from Government Ministries and

Column: 290

departments and from the community, voluntary welfare organisations and religious organisations, and from the Judiciary.  And I believe that this should be led by a well-respected leader of not just the community, but of the republic, perhaps the President of the republic himself.  This tribunal should have sufficient powers and resources to make policy decisions, enforce and review legislation and regulations on gambling, develop, monitor and enforce strategies and initiate and support services for the management of problem gambling.  It should amongst its functions ensure optimum coordination between all agencies, both Government and non-Government agencies, that are involved in the regulation and control of gambling and prevention, mitigation and treatment of the effects of problem gambling.  It should be able to handle formal complaints against both casinos and other gambling operators as well as Government agencies which are involved in the regulation of these industries, and it should allow appeals against its decisions of all the above.  It should handle feedback from the public, from gambling addicts and their families. 

 

     I think one important role that it would have is to ensure the effective implementation of the exclusion clause.  Two MPs before me, Dr Warren Lee and Mr Sin Boon Ann, have talked about the exclusion clause.  I too am very interested in this clause and how the Government is going to implement it.  To my knowledge, we are the only country that is proposing that it be extended to family members.  I applaud this.  I think this is going to be one of the potentially most effective safeguards that we have in place.  I think this is one of the areas where we can really make a difference, as we had before when we embarked on something new.  But this is also an area which is potentially very controversial.  I am not clear - I do not think anyone is yet - as to which of the family members will be allowed to exercise this.  Is it just spouses, children,

Column: 291

parents, grandparents, siblings?  And under what circumstances, what evidence do you have to show, how stringently will it be enforced?  I can foresee some interesting ramifications, knowing what a kiasu society we are, where parents, perhaps the moment their children reach the age of 21, can put their children's names down for exclusion.  Or people, maybe as a condition of getting married, could put their spouses' names down for exclusion.

 

     I think how we implement this and how we draw up the guidelines will be an important exercise.  As has been expressed by some of the other Members, I think to give a name directly to the casino would not be the right way to go about it.  This is where I think that an independent gambling tribunal would play a very crucial role, an impartial role, and a role that would implement this safety net in an effective and sensitive way as well as protecting families and individuals rather than disrupting them.

 

     I should now like to move on to the integrated resort concept and what I think of it.  The Cabinet has explained why an integrated resort is considered the most economic and viable model for a casino in Singapore.  I have no argument against that.  But I see it as analogous to a drug company deciding that sugar-coated pills are the most marketable form of drugs.  But sugar-coated pills, no matter how fake the sugar is, even if it is 95% or 98%, and the drug component is only 5% or 2%, they are still  marketed as drugs by pharmacies.  They are not marketed as sweets, and they have the necessary warnings and precautions of their potential risks.  In fact, any responsible pharmacist or distributor recognises that they are potentially more dangerous because they can be mistaken as sweets and, therefore, they should be treated with even greater care to prevent them harming the unwary, particularly young children in this case.

 

Column: 292

     Similarly, therefore, the non-gambling component of an IR, even if it comprises a bulk of the IR, does not neutralise the potential  for harm of a gambling component.  The Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports has described the comprehensive network of safeguards, including no advertising in the mass media for casinos.  But I would like to raise the question here as to what about advertising for the integrated resorts.  I presume you cannot ban advertising in Singapore for the integrated resorts.  But extensive advertising of the integrated resort without warning of the dangers of a casino and casino gambling can be as insidious and harmful as marketing sugar-coated drugs and sweets.  So, I would urge us all to clearly recognise that the IR does have a potential to do harm because it does have a casino in it and we should have stringent warnings and safeguards in place.

 

     I should like to conclude by asking, hypothetically, what an integrated resort can and cannot do for Singapore.  After a protracted debate in the community, and in the House, and a difficult, even painful, decision, we are going ahead with IRs to revive our flagging tourist industry and to create jobs, particularly jobs for older and less well-trained workers.  But I should like to ask: how long can we expect these beneficial effects to last?  Is this a long-term solution?  It is being recognised that Singapore has few natural assets that attract tourists and we have to constantly reinvent and remake ourselves to remain competitive.  And I think we have done very well on this front.  But, unfortunately, these make-overs can be copied by other countries.  They have been copied by other countries.  And, of course, in many situations, the copier can improve on the original model.  So I believe that integrated resorts can make us the flavour of the month, maybe the flavour of several seasons, I hope.  But I very much doubt if IRs will catapult us to the league of great cities. 

 

Column: 293

     The Prime Minister spoke about the difference between great cities and wannabes.  In my opinion, the difference between a great city and a wannabe is that the former has a definite identity that it is confident and comfortable with. It may wish to refine itself.  They often do, as cited.  New York cleaned itself up; Paris had the Pyramid put in by I M Pei, a top architect.  These do enhance it.  But people would still go and visit them, whether they did these refinements or not.  And sometimes, if they try to over-refine, like Paris with Euro-Disney, a lot of people think that it actually detracts from the essence of the city. 

 

     So, a great city does not have to fundamentally change.  It can do a few cosmetic adjustments.  But it does not need to do any more.  It should not do any more.  On the other hand, wannabes are constantly making over themselves.  They are changing themselves and copying themselves all the time because they have no core identity.  They are always trying to follow someone else.  They have no solid foundation.  On this, I would say that I somewhat disagree with Mr Philip Ng.  I do not think that Singapore is a wannabe. We may not be a great city in all aspects, but I think we have the makings of a great city.  In many aspects, we are already successful in that we have these core values that other cities want to emulate or copy. 

 

     Maybe I could illustrate with an example.  I was in Paris last month.  Of course, I had a wonderful time.  I enjoyed the museums, the art exhibitions, the food, the architecture.  I also had the opportunity to have dinner on my last night with some old friends who had lived in Singapore before.  They are Americans, international lawyers.  They had lived in New York, Tokyo, Singapore and now

Column:294
