     But there was another reason why I felt strongly against the casino and it was a more personal one.  I  have seen up close how relatives and friends - good people with responsible jobs - could become helpless gambling addicts and lose their savings, their homes and their dignity, and their families suffered. 

 

    Sir, I have spoken on this publicly.  I have made my concerns known also privately to some Ministers.  But just as I wanted the Government to keep an open mind to my views and to listen to my concerns, I have also sought to keep an open mind to its views on the subject.  It is only fair and right in an open democratic debate on national issues.  It has to be a two-sided conversation aimed at reaching the best possible decision in the interest of the country as a whole.  It cannot be that I expect the Government to listen to my views on the issue and to take them seriously while I shut my ears to its views. 

 

     So I have listened very closely to the Ministerial speeches over the last two days.  It became clear to me that the concerns and fears that I had, which were also voiced by many Singaporeans who were against the casino, were recognised and also shared by the Government.  And that, in particular, some Ministers, such

Column: 313

as Mr Lim Boon Heng and Mr Wong Kan Seng, were also deeply vexed about the possible negative effects of a casino, and that the decision to go ahead was not an easy one for them.  This gives anti-casino Singaporeans, like myself, the confidence that our views had also been reflected vigorously at the highest level and not brushed aside as being immature, soft or, perhaps worse, as being pre-modern, backwater-loving moralists.  This equal respect for the legitimate views of those in the anti-casino camp is important, or else it would breed cynicism and alienation among those who had spoken up because they cared. 

 

     Indeed, one of the depressing aspects of this debate is the sense that many people did not - and still do not - believe the Government when it said that it had not made up its mind on the casino issue until the date when the special meeting was held among the Cabinet. Some said that the feedback exercise had been a farce and a waste of time.  Sir, why do they think that, despite all the pronouncements to the contrary?  I do believe the Government when it said that it did not make up its mind until the moment when a decision needed to be made.  One reason, I think, was how the Government  framed the argument in the beginning and how the leaders and the people had very different conceptions of what it meant when it said "to open the doors to a casino".  I think most Singaporeans have not been to the integrated resorts, with a casino component, in the Atlantis or Bellagio, and we have in mind casinos like the sort that they would have in Las Vegas and Macau.  Therefore, we were talking at cross-purposes.  And the more the Government pushed the line about whether we are a mature society or not, the more those of us who felt that we do not want a Macau and a Las Vegas stuck to our ground. Sir, there is a sense that we were not being heard, but

Column:314

actually we were just speaking on very different wavelengths.

 

     Another reason, I believe, is the call for a request for concept which provided the casino option for both sites.  I felt that if a request for concept for an IR without a casino component for one of the sites, say, the Marina Bayfront, has been called, that means no casinos involved, that would have at least given the public a chance to see if this is indeed a dead idea, a really no-brainer, with no takers, because it would just not be viable.  Or perhaps, for all we know, there might have been a few good concepts coming in, perhaps viable, given the prime location of the area and Singapore's brand name.  But because we have called for concept proposals for both sites, which include the casino component, or given them the option of including a casino, now we seem tied to the idea.  I do not think it gives us much comfort when the Government says that, "Oh, because the concepts with casinos have come in from all over the world, from top brand names, from well-known people, what will the world think of us now if we have to say no?"  And so we have to say yes to both.  We are also worried about where the investments from the other potential bidders would go, or whether they would go to another region.  The question then arises, all the more perhaps, that we should have called for a request for concepts with the casino element for one then, perhaps just in Sentosa.  Indeed, I would have liked to start with just one IR with a casino in Sentosa, which is less accessible to Singaporeans and can be considered "overseas", to see the effects and to see if we could manage the social fallout, and to see if such an IR with a small gaming component could be successful in drawing the crowds, especially the tourists, before deciding to open up the area in other parts of the island to more IRs with casinos.

 

     That being said, I must say in all fairness that the Government did put up a

Column: 315

compelling case for opening our doors to an IR with a casino over the last few days.  And the clincher for me, like for Mr Lim Boon Heng, is the jobs created.  Like gambling addiction, joblessness can also lead to severe social problems such as broken families, bankruptcies, suicides and crime.  And I think, for the average Singaporean and the community as a whole, joblessness is a greater scourge than gambling addiction.  Indeed, in my meet-the-people sessions, I see more problems cropping up from people not being able to find and keep jobs than from gambling addiction.  But that is not to say that we should not go all out to combat gambling addiction.  Indeed, I notice that all the Ministers who spoke did not try to minimise the potential social fallout of having casinos.  Indeed, they confronted the issues head-on and listed many new and bold initiatives to tackle the problems that may arise from having casinos, including strict law enforcement measures. 

 

     At the visit with the MPs to view the concepts and models proposed by the potential bidders late last week, I paid special attention to the location of the casino in the premises of the proposed concepts, its prominence and size.  And I was assured to note that, in most proposals, they were understated, very tasteful, and not offered as a key attraction.

 

     All that said, however, I must say I still have some concerns about the decision which I hope will be addressed by the Government.  I will highlight three.

 

     The first relates to the economic merits of the case.  The entire premise of the go-ahead rests on the assumption that these integrated resorts will be successful in attracting tourists, with the revenue generated mainly from its casinos, and hence create jobs and add to our economic growth.  But how confident is the Government that Singapore can sustain two IRs of this magnitude, with such

Column:316

small gaming components, and that the tourists will be able to provide the flow and the numbers?  I am not saying, of course, that we should increase the gaming component.  But I worry if the resort operators will make a case for it at a later stage for their economic viability, especially since it has been made clear that the casinos will be the economic engines of the IRs. 

 

     As Minister Lim Hng Kiang noted, the integrated resort with the smallest gaming component presently is the Atlantis in Bahamas and it has a gaming component of about 25%.  What assurance do we have that the operators in Singapore will not one day say that, responding to the changing circumstances and trends, they need to expand the casino in the resorts here?  Or, if they prove unable to attract foreigners in droves, and they turn to the Government to relax the rules on the casinos, to attract more Singaporeans to patronise them, can the Government hold firm, especially given their iconic status and the world is watching?

 

     Also, the integrated resorts will be up and running only in five years.

That seems like a long time, enough time for others in the region to join the race to build casinos within integrated resorts and also lure the crowds.  What will then be our edge? 

 

     My second concern relates to the longer-term demands on our resources to deal with the casino-related problems.  Singaporeans will benefit from the jobs created when the integrated resorts first come in, but the problems which may arise in terms of problem gambling, bankruptcies and crime, will only rear their ugly head many years later.  Are we prepared to pour in the resources and deal with the problems in the long haul?

 

     I read a recent study by Economics Professor Ernie Goss and Law Professor Edward Morse on the varying bankruptcy

Column:317

effects over the life-cycle of the casino.  This study is the first to look at the impact of casinos over a 12-year period, from 1990 to 2002.  It compared the personal bankruptcy rates in casino and non-casino counties and tracked the longer-term consequences of introducing gambling.  They found that after an initial increase in personal bankruptcy rates, rates declined and levelled out for an additional two or three years, followed by progressively increasing rates.   Compared with a non-casino county, the casino county is expected to have higher overall bankruptcy filings than the non-casino county after the ninth-year of operations, with progressively increasing rates thereafter.  The study raises possible explanations for these life-cycle effects.  Casinos may have positive economic effects in the initial years as they provide jobs and other economic benefits including a large influx of tourists and non-residents who come to gamble and enjoy in the entertainment complexes.  But over time, as the casinos mature and other localities open up competing facilities, they speculate that the number of tourists begins to drop at the same time that the number of problem gamblers increases.

 

     This brings me to the urgent need for independent and rigorous research in Singapore to help us understand better what draws Singaporeans to gambling in the first place, why some become problem gamblers, and how to treat them.  And we should carry out these studies before the IRs open in 2009. 

 

     The recent MCYS study on gambling is useful in giving us the baseline and a snapshot of the situation today.  It found that, as we know, about 58% of Singaporeans aged 18 and above already gamble.  A minority of 2.1% are probably compulsive gamblers.  This is quite an eye-opener because the percentage of probable problem gamblers is higher than Macau's

Column:318

1.8%.  Macau is presently the king of casinos in the region, with 17 casinos.  How is it that we seem to have overtaken Macau in producing problem gamblers even before a single casino is built?  Even if we allow for statistical error, it would seem too close for comfort.

 

     We need to understand why.  I think the prevailing culture and social attitudes play a role.  Gambling is very much a part of the Chinese culture.  You see the Chinese gambling during the Chinese New Year and at solemn occasions like the funeral wake. You see the children taking part in these gambling sessions, especially over Chinese New Year.  If there is a road accident, you can be sure the Chinese are rushing to copy down the car plate licence number to buy 4-D rather than helping out those who are injured.  I do not know of any other cultural group which does that.  But that still does not answer the question of why we have more probable compulsive gamblers than Macau because we have mainly the same ethnic composition, in terms of the majority Chinese.

 

      Sir, we need to invest more in research to identify in each community: values and attitudes towards gambling, the nature and extent of gambling activities, the prevalence of problem gambling, and the resources and strategies available to mitigate problem gambling.  The resulting data will help individual communities to raise people's awareness about problem gambling and to plan for prevention and treatment services.  Going by the limited research that is focused on problem gamblers, especially those found in other countries, it is hard to define a personality factor that distinguishes compulsive gamblers from other people.  It can be the average Joe.  It can be a person who has a very high moral standing in society.

 

      However, studies have found that compulsive gamblers have more irrational beliefs about gambling.  For example, they

Column:319

are more likely to believe that they can beat the house.  So no matter how much we tell them that they cannot beat the house, they still believe irrationally that they can.  We have to find out what works in preventing gambling problems that already exist in Singapore today and those who go to cruise ships and Genting.  We have to understand what can we do to mitigate even those problems today.  Singapore has much experience in public campaigns and public education programmes to prevent what are considered social ills, such as smoking and drink driving.  Can we also apply similar approaches to problem gambling?

 

     Sir, I would urge the Government to see research as a strategic investment to improve our ability to understand how and why some people develop gambling problems and how to use resources most effectively to prevent problems and provide treatment.  Investment in problem gambling research will also reflect a tangible commitment to finding solutions for serious problems that affect not only individuals, but also their families and communities.

 

     Sir, this research can be funded directly from gambling revenues received by the Government.  Perhaps, the Government can work out a formula which assigns a percentage of the gross slot machine revenues to research.  This is being done in some countries like Ontario. 

 

      Sir, my third concern revolves around the future that we want to create for Singapore, our home.  I feel this is at the heart of the issue.  In his Budget speech this year, the Prime Minister has painted a vision of Singapore as a land of opportunity for all, a home with strong community bonds and values worth living for and fighting for.  It is a vision that all Singaporeans can share and look forward to.  However, more and more Singaporeans find themselves confronted by difficult choices at every turn - having to

Column:320

choose between many competing concepts of family values, sexual morality, and social justice, which they should advocate and defend.

 

     Yesterday's easy choices are today fraught with ambiguous moral tones as the world becomes more globalised and we are no longer insulated from what happens in the most liberal parts of the world.  We need to reach a new and fresh consensus on where we want to go, the sort of society we want to become and pass on to future generations. 

 

     Many in this House have noted that cities all around the world are reinventing themselves, such as New York, and some, such as London, Sydney and Geneva, already have casinos without damaging their reputations as respectable places.  That is true.  But note that all these examples quoted also celebrate more liberal and free-wheeling lifestyles.  Hence, having a casino in their midst is consistent with their social and traditional ethos.  Another important difference: if the citizens of the UK do not like the lifestyle in London or the citizens of the US do not like the life of the Big Apple, they can live elsewhere in their vast countries.  And I do have good friends in the UK with strong family values who prefer to live in less exciting places, like Surrey, than in London even though they could well afford to live in the capital.

 

     But Singaporeans do not have such choices as Singapore is both a city and a country.  So it is all the more important that all sectors of society be brought on board when deciding on issues such as this which have a bearing on the kind of society we want to become.  Otherwise, some might feel that this is not the home they want to live in, and migrate.  Also, some people mentioned Sydney.  Sydney may be a vibrant and safe city on the surface, but it is in actual fact today grappling with serious criminal activity arising from its popular Star City Casino

Column:321

which was set up nine years ago.  Recently, Sydney formed a new Casino Investigation Unit after an inquiry into reports of serious criminal activity at the casino which include claims that loan sharks force women to pay back debts by prostituting themselves.  It is reports like this that make you a bit worried. 

 

     Sir, if given a choice, I would not want a casino on our shores.  But having heard the arguments put forward by the Government, it would appear that we have little choice, not if we want multi-billion dollar investments with tens of thousands of jobs for our citizens and to create the land of opportunity for all with buzz.  However, as citizens, we do have a choice in whether we want to be regulars at a casino or not, and in how we can put our best efforts into making sure that the integrated resort will work in the best interest of all Singaporeans, with minimal social costs exacted.  Then we will indeed be Uniquely Singapore - fun, vibrant, cosmopolitan, but still distinctly Asian, wholesome and safe.

 

     I was not around when Mr Low Thia Khiang spoke yesterday.  But I read in the Straits Times that he likened the resort's proposal to porridge that was being cooked and served to Singaporeans.  They were then told to take it as there was special medicine in it and that this medicine could cause some people diarrhoea or dehydration and even lose their lives but to take it, and then the PM would do what is necessary for the aftercare.  This analogy is misleading and insidious.  This is not what the Government is advocating - to take porridge with, almost like poison laced in it.  It is more like a grand buffet.  I see it as a grand buffet aimed at drawing big crowds, creating excitement in Singapore. There is one stall that sells something that may not be very healthy for you, and there are barricades.  The people there

Column: 322

say, "Don't go and eat there.  It is for those who want this sort of food, but it is not good for you.  Enjoy the rest of the buffet."  There are a lot of things to do, and it is a place that you want to be identified with.  But there is this booth, "Don't go.  It is bad."  I think the Government has made clear over the last few days that it is not promoting casino.  It does not want to promote gambling.  There was no poison being served to Singaporeans; there was no special medicine with after effects that were meant to cause Singaporeans ill.

 

     Sir, I have no doubt that this Government has made this decision in the best interest of this country and society, after weighing very carefully the pros and cons.  I would urge all those who have spoken up against the casino to join PM Lee and the Government to make this work for Singaporeans and to work together to make sure this is a plus for Singapore as a tourist destination and as a home for all citizens.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: May I have your permission to clarify what the hon. Member has just said?

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Okay.  I will allow one clarification.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: She said that my description of the Government's decision by using porridge is incorrect.  I would like to clarify that it is correct in the sense that it is being forced down just like porridge gets down in the throat.  She said that it should be more appropriate to describe the situation as a buffet.  Sir, that is exactly the danger.  I said earlier on that my mind was firmed up after I looked at the concept plans because the whole thing was so attractive. You look at it as a family resort, it is harmless, as what Ms Irene Ng said. You look at the buffet, it is so nice and, inadvertently, you are attracted to it without knowing the danger. You eat the buffet and you also

Column:323

eat something which is harmful to you, or you may be attracted to it later on. How much of it, we do not know.  Can Ms Irene Ng tell us that everybody can be insulated from eating just the correct buffet, and not the other one?  How does she do it?

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong: Mr Low has been in the House and he has heard all the social safeguards that will be put in place.  The casino will be like this small stall in the corner - no signs, no bright lights - and a clear sign saying it is dangerous, "Please don't go."  A barricade with $100 fee to get in and various safeguards to make sure that Singaporeans are not tempted.  But we also acknowledge, and it is clear from the speeches made, that there is a risk.  Therefore, we must take all steps as a society - and the VWOs should get on board - to make sure that we can mitigate the negative effects.  We are not saying that there is none.  But we are saying that we will do our best to mitigate it.  I think we can.

     The Minister of State for Finance and Transport (Mrs Lim Hwee Hua): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, for a non-gambler, I certainly have visited quite a number of casino-related developments from the mass market, somewhat un-glam casinos to the imposing integrated resorts similar to those being proposed.

 

     My first introduction was to a casino in Macau almost two decades ago, where I witnessed an unpretentious, raw offering to all and sundry. This left a rather negative imprint on my mind as there was virtually nothing between the tempted and the temptation. I contributed a very small sum to the jackpot machines but my loss was nothing compared to the lives that gambling addiction must have wrecked.

 

     In the late 80s when I was studying in Los Angeles, my husband and I would occasionally cover Las Vegas in our many drives around the country. And we would

Column: 324

sometimes take our two young children in tow, not to the casinos but to the wide variety of family-friendly entertainment. We have been back in between the years and we never cease to be amazed at the way newer and more creative offerings have emerged over time.

 

     Las Vegas was where I was intrigued by the hypnotic effect gambling seemed to have on its victims - I saw how addiction was manifested as a hopeful but dazed looking gambler, lost in time, straddled across two stools in front of two one-arm bandit machines, cigarette or free drink in one hand and the lever in the other. They just would not give up on a machine until they ran out of cash

or they hit the jackpot.  While I was feeding mine with nickels literally just for fun, the addict was altogether serious about recouping his losses.  For the record, I never ventured beyond the jackpot machines nor lost more than $200 each time.

 

     Everywhere you turn, there is a machine to greet you or, should I say, to tempt you.  Even at the border between California and Nevada, there are machines to welcome you.  There are also machines to help you out of your guilt trip - you feed in nickels or the five-cent coins, but you can bet in multiples, which somehow beguiles you into thinking that you are gambling small.

 

     Las Vegas is where I saw instant gratification, down to the quickie marriages.  Las Vegas is all about easy money, fast bucks, and not about values.  Yet, Las Vegas is also where my two young children were able to enjoy circus acts to their fill and had theme park rides aplenty.  It is where we caught up with world-class performances, from pop stars to magic shows to musicals.

 

     Sir, some Singaporeans have commented that the day the Government decides to proceed with the casino is a

Column:325

sad day indeed.  Sir, I can understand their sadness.  As many of my colleagues have articulated, many are objecting to the very idea of a casino operating right here in Singapore for very good and fundamental reasons.

 

     Firstly, on ethical grounds, that it is simply wrong to conduct a business that exploits human weakness;


     Secondly, that it propagates the wrong philosophy of easy money and breeds the wrong values;


     Thirdly, because of the adverse impact of addiction on families; and

 

     Fourthly, that there will be a permanent dent on our wholesome and upright image. 

 

     Let me briefly elaborate on each in turn.

 

     Firstly, the opposition on ethical grounds.  Given the addictive nature of gambling, easy access to a casino which operates round the clock, or 24 by 7 in today's language, provides untold temptation for a quick fix.  The weaker spirit will not be able to stay away for too long from the casino, unlike other forms of gambling, unless there are barriers to continuous or excessive patronage.  Strict enforcement of the entry levy and membership fee will therefore be all-important.

 

     Secondly, wrong philosophy, wrong values.  Sir, I share the concern that the very presence of a casino will reinforce the view that one can make a fast buck by simply taking a chance, a gamble, and without having to work hard.  Once this sets in, the young will grow up accepting that gambling is part and parcel of modern living or, worse still, the norm.  This is already evident elsewhere where some

Column:326

students have gambled away all their school fees.  The reality is really the larger challenge of modern living where people increasingly seek to make easy money or instant gratification.  It should be noted that the same can be said of hopeful punters at the stock market or speculators during a property boom.  The difference is perhaps in the amount of capital needed for reckless risk-taking to set in.  In the final analysis, the question is: can we really sterilise or insulate Singaporeans from what they would regard as opportunities to strike it rich?

 

     Thirdly, the adverse impact on the family.  The single most heartfelt concern must be found in the plight of the victims of gambling addiction.  Without a doubt, women and children are typically at the receiving end.  Addiction can reduce an otherwise responsible father and husband to a helpless and desperate criminal or parasite to his family.  The shame and suffering, even if it is true of a minority, should not be trivialised.  Sir, this concern is valid, and the question is really whether a casino will lead to a sharp rise in addiction that is unmanageable.

 

     Fourthly, on the erosion of our wholesome image.  The most endearing feature of Singapore must be our wholesome image, that Singapore stands for safe families and an honest and secure environment.  Expatriates frequently cite these as Singapore's distinct advantage when deciding where to locate.  Now that we have decided to proceed with an integrated resort with a casino component, what will they think?  More importantly, what will our own Singaporeans think?  Do they see this as a slippery slope where the introduction of one vice will quickly multiply into other forms, such as prostitution, triad activities or money laundering?  Or that once the idea of a casino becomes reality, there will be less resistance to allowing, say, video poker machines, to proliferate everywhere.  In

Column: 327

the US, this convenience has hooked many women onto gambling as well. 

 

     Sir, against all these concerns, I can understand why there is so much scepticism over the compensating effect of the economic benefits.  The question is often asked, "Are we so desperate that we need to sacrifice social values for uncertain economic costs?"  

 

     Sir, there is merit in seeing things in perspective.  For one, what the Government is approving is an integrated resort development and not a pure casino project.  As I have recounted earlier on, my family and I have thoroughly enjoyed ourselves at the non-gaming components of these developments elsewhere.  Neither is the IR concept used to camouflage or mask the underlying gambling activity.  I am hopeful that when the proposals are finally submitted, it would be quite evident that serious money would be devoted to serious entertainment propositions, and that the gaming component would be a small part.

 

     So, are the economic benefits worth it?  This is the very question that the Cabinet has had to grapple with and one to be answered, with national interests in mind.  Proceeding with the IR concept does not mean that the Government has trivialised the consequential social ills or disregarded the fears of erosion of social values.  And, most certainly, the decision does not imply that the Government thinks opponents to the idea care any less about the economic future of Singapore.  In fact, it is precisely because the opponents cared, that they bothered to speak up with such conviction.  Sir, this decision is really about the Government taking a pragmatic view of the pros and cons, against a backdrop of real and intensifying competition for the tourism dollar.

 

     So, is this a situation of  "If you can't beat them, join them?"  Yes and no;  yes, because most new tourism offerings are

Column:328

designed to meet the needs of the faster growing segments, especially the MICE segment.  Hence, the offerings would have rather similar elements across countries.  No, because we are not joining them, as we are imposing strict safeguards even as we are improving our tourism appeal.

  

     So, is the 18th of April a sad day?  Sir, I think, not necessarily.  It need not be a sad day, because the Government has committed to ensuring that there are sufficient and strict safeguards against any rising social problems.  There will be increased employment and more economic activity.  It need not be a sad day, because I know that the many people who have spoken out valiantly against this, especially the voluntary and religious groups, will remain committed to supporting families in distress and counselling addicts, and will continue their good work of teaching values to the young, with or without a casino.  It need not be a sad day because, ultimately, every one of us has the choice of patronising the gaming activity or not.

 

     But, Sir, much as I have reservations, I know it would definitely be a sad day when it becomes obvious that IRs have worked elsewhere with manageable social consequences, but with Singapore trailing behind without one.

     The Senior Minister, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I rise to state my position on gambling and the casino issue.

 

     I do not approve of gambling, but I am not anti-gambling.  I take a practical, realistic and balanced view of life.  There will always be gambling, just as there will always be prostitution and alcoholism.  These vices are as old as human civilisation.  I do not condone them, but I accept them as part of our society.  We cannot eradicate them, so we have to manage them.


Column:329

     I have gambled, but only infrequently, and I would add, in a most timid way.  When Toto was introduced in 1968, like many Singaporeans, I played for the fun of it.  But after a few times, the novelty wore off.  I never struck any prize.  I have also bought sweepstake tickets.  When I first started work, I had a car loan and housing mortgage to service.  I had a young family.  So, I wishfully thought that if I could strike a lottery, it would lighten, and perhaps even settle, my loan burden.  I bought one ticket at a time.  I believed that if Lady Luck smiled on you, one ticket would be enough.  If she did not, a hundred tickets would make no difference.  I had no luck.  In all, I probably did not spend more than $100 on sweepstake.  That is throughout my life, much less than Hwee Hua's visit to Las Vegas on jackpot!


     I have also played the 4-D on special occasions like when I had a new car.  When I became the Managing Director of Neptune Orient Lines, the company provided me with a Mercedes-Benz.  I bought its licence plate number.  The number never came up.  Instead, the number plate of my Ford Cortina, which I had sold off, came out.  My friend who bought my car grinned from ear to ear; he bought 4-D. Last year, I bought my own car after I stepped down as Prime Minister.  I thought that, after having served dutifully as Prime Minister for nearly 14 years, Lady Luck might be a little kinder this time.  I bought the number of my car over four weekends.  I was poorer by $80.


     I have never gambled on card games.  I make a distinction between card games and number games like Toto and Sweepstake.  One is active, a waste of time and can be addictive.  The other is passive and less likely to be addictive.


     Yes, I have been inside a casino - not one but two.  The first time was - you

Column: 330

will never guess - in Africa.  I had accompanied Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew to Lusaka, Zambia, for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in 1979.  Dhanabalan, Lim Chee Onn and Eugene Yap were there too.  We stayed in a hotel while PM Lee stayed in a guest house which was specially built for the occasion.  Before the meeting started, the four of us felt bored.  There was nothing to do.  We did not, and we dared not, stray far away from the hotel, just in case PM Lee called us for a meeting.  There was a casino in the hotel, so we decided to see what it looked like.  The four of us had never been inside a casino.  We went in.  It was morning.  There were no gamblers around.  But the croupier, a friendly African, beckoned us and offered to play with us.  I had never heard of Black Jack or Baccarat.  But there was a roulette table.  I thought the game was simple enough - a no-brainer - just put some coins on some numbers, you roll and you would strike it, if you are lucky.  Chee Onn and I decided to try our hand at it.  Dhanabalan did not because of his religious belief.  Eugene also did not take part.  There was a certain innocence in him.  I picked two numbers and betted a dollar on each number.  The friendly African gave the roulette a friendly spin.  The ball gave my numbers a miss.  I tried two more times.  Lost again.  I left the casino, richer for the experience but six dollars poorer.  You might call me a low roller.


     The second time I went into a casino was in 1989.  I was on an official visit to Kuala Lumpur as Minister for Defence.  My host and counterpart, Tengku Rithaudeen, took me up to Genting Highlands to play golf.  In our flight were Najib Razak and Ahmad Mattar.  We stayed overnight in Genting Highlands.  That night, the owners of Genting Highlands took me to their casino.  My Malaysian hosts, of course, did not join us.

They would not have been allowed in anyway.  Lim Goh Tong and his son explained to me the various games, the security arrangements and the

Column:331

surveillance cameras and systems that they had in place.  More interestingly, Lim Goh Tong related how he managed to secure the concession for Genting Highlands.  One day, when he saw the uninhabited Genting Highlands or mountain ranges in Pahang, he visualised a holiday resort.  But the holiday resort on its own, even in the cool highlands, would not be economically successful.  There were no roads, no electricity, no water, no infrastructure, just virgin jungle.  So he persuaded Prime Minister Tunku Abdul Rahman to give him a gaming licence in return for developing a resort on Genting. Tunku Abdul Rahman agreed. Today, Genting and Malaysia are much better for it.  What was once virgin jungle and uninhabitable mountains have become prized real estate. Genting Highlands Resort has generated billions of dollars for Malaysia.  

 

     Can we develop a mega holiday resort or a mega Meetings, Incentives, Conventions and Exhibitions (MICE) centre without a gaming facility?  If the answer is yes, then the casino question would not have arisen at all. Unfortunately, the answer is no.  Hence, the debate over the past year. But the debate is not really over whether we should or should not have a casino.  It is whether we should forgo the integrated resort because of its gaming component.  It is about our economic future over the increase in social costs.  It is about families who would benefit from the jobs created versus families who could have their lives destroyed because of gambling.  It is about whether we want to have a vibrant, cosmopolitan and fun Singapore or a fuddy-duddy Singapore.

 

     I was not in Singapore when Cabinet deliberated on the issue on 9th April.  I was in Qatar.  But before I left, I sent an email to Prime Minister Lee giving him my views. He circulated my views to Cabinet.  I was for moving on to the next stage of

Column:332

the project, which is Request for Proposals.  I gave four reasons:

 

     -  Credibility of Singapore and how we are perceived;

 

     -  Economic benefits;

 

     -  Easy access to existing casinos; and

 

     -  Manageable incremental social cost. 

 

     I shall elaborate on the reasons which I gave to PM.

 

     Right from the beginning, I kept an open mind on the casino question. When the subject was first broached by George Yeo, the Minister for Trade and Industry, PM and many Ministers were against it. The project nearly did not see the light of day. 

 

     But George Yeo persisted. As the Minister in charge of the economy, he had to persist.  I was not for or against the Integrated Resort with casino at that stage.  I kept an open mind.  I was aware of the religious, moral and social objections.  But I also knew the economic opportunities we would miss if we were to forgo the Integrated Resort.  More importantly, I was concerned over Singapore's future as a vibrant, cosmopolitan city.  During those discussions, I said that I would make up my mind only after I knew what kind of integrated resorts there would be.  I did not believe in arguing in a vacuum.  I therefore supported George's proposal to proceed to Request for Concepts stage.  Therefore, those people who think that we have already decided on the casino were wrong.  Many of us did not decide until we had seen the bids from the potential investors.


     On 5th March, together with PM and other Ministers, I attended the briefing on the 19 proposals for an Integrated Resort.  Having seen for myself the scale, boldness, creativity and seriousness of most

Column:333

of the proposals, I support going ahead with the Integrated Resort.


     At stake are our credibility and how the world will perceive us.  The 13 bidders have put in a lot of time and effort to come up with serious proposals for Integrated Resorts with theme parks or MICE.  They are internationally well-known.  They are global players.  Not to proceed to the next stage now implies that the proposals are without merit, which cannot be so.  It will hurt our international credibility and reputation.  We will be seen to be incapable of making rational decisions.  We will be regarded as timid and not being serious about Remaking Singapore.  We will be seen as lacking boldness in mapping Singapore's future in a fast-changing world.


     Second, economic benefits.  Having seen the proposals, I believe the economic benefits are big.  I believe the Integrated Resorts will reinvigorate our tourism industry.  Our tourist attractions are dated and lack excitement.

 

     Recently, when I was in Jakarta, an Indonesian businessman asked me whether Singapore was going ahead with the casino.  I told him that we were in the process of making a decision.  He said that he was ambivalent about the casino but he saw no choice for Singapore.  He said that we had no exciting tourist attractions  and he himself did not bring his family members to Singapore often.  Whatever they wanted to buy, they could buy in Jakarta.  They have been to our Night Safari and other attractions but he said once was enough.  But if we had world-class entertainment in the Integrated Resort, he said he would come often with his family members and friends to enjoy the entertainment.

 

     What he said struck me.  Static tourist sights will not attract repeat visitors.  So

Column: 334

we are after repeat visitors, not just visitors coming here once and never come back again.  But the ever-changing scene of world-class entertainment will.  Entertainment never becomes dated if the IR operators can bring in new top rate singers, dancers and other shows.  If the operators can bring in big names, tourists will come from all over the region to listen to the singers and watch the shows.  Big names like Celine Dion, Elton John and Rod Stewart who now perform in Las Vegas, and big shows like Cirque du Soleil, that is, a circus without animals but with human beings performing in a very interesting manner, from Canada and Crazy Horse from Paris.


     When I was in Kuwait, one of the Ministers also asked me about the casino.  He understood our need for a casino as part of an Integrated Resort.  I asked him whether Arabs gambled.  He said many did and they gambled in London and Europe.


     I have been visiting China and India regularly for many years.  I have seen the breath-taking transformations there.  I have also been visiting countries in the Middle East.  You should see the ambitions and the pace and scale of developments in places like Dubai and Qatar.  Dubai is growing on the back of Arab oil wealth.  Qatar has plenty of gas, oil, sand and land and wants to use these resources to build a modern country.  They are not just targeting Arabs but also tourists from all over the world.  So it is not just Singapore competing with Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong and China for tourism.  We are also competing against Dubai, Qatar and other countries in the Middle East.


     Dubai already has many skyscrapers but is constructing the world's tallest building.  When completed, Dubai Tower, expected to be at least 750 metres high, will be more than 300 metres higher than the Petronas Twin Towers.  Dubai Mall, the world's largest shopping mall, is also being built.  It has 3.6 million square feet

Column:335

net retail space.  This is equivalent to six Suntec Cities.  The mall will have 14,000 car park lots.  In Dubai, whatever they do, they want to be the biggest; size matters.  But is Dubai just being vain or after the tourist dollars?  No.  Dubai knows that its oil reserves will one day run out.  It is therefore building a new future for itself, diversifying its economy and lessening its oil dependency.  In fact, Dubai's model is Singapore - the way we organise ourselves and our can-do attitude.  Whatever we do which are successful, they copy and do it on a larger scale.


     Qatar, an Arab country of less than one million people, is about 10 to 15 years behind Dubai in development.  But it wants to surpass Dubai.  Its attitude reminds me of the lyrics from the song in Annie Get Your Gun:  "Anything you can do, I can do better".  The Emir of Qatar told me that they did not want to simply copy Dubai because Dubai is a city while Qatar is a country.  They have more oil and gas than Dubai.  They want to be different and better than Dubai.  They are confident of eclipsing Dubai in 15 to 20 years' time.

 

     Dubai is now the aviation hub in the Middle East.  Qatar wants to compete.  It is building a US$5 billion airport with a capacity for 50 million passengers.  Qatari Airways aspires to catch up and outstrip Emirates.  These two airlines will put pressure on SIA.  And the two airports, Dubai and Doha in Qatar, will compete with Changi Airport.

 

     To attract tourists and people to live and work in Qatar, Qatar is building The Pearl Qatar to match Dubai's Palm Island and The World.  This is a US$2.5 billion man-made island covering 985 acres of reclaimed land offshore.  Our Marina Centre is only 208 acres or less than one quarter the size of The Pearl Qatar.


     There are many other big scale projects which Qatar is embarking on. 

Column:336

Money is no object.  Brand names matter.  They want the best so that they can become "the leading centre for business, leisure, sports and education".


     Dubai and Qatar are not re-inventing themselves.

They are inventing themselves in a big and bold way.  Fortunately, Dubai and Qatar are not building any casinos.  They are Muslim countries.  If we reject the integrated resorts with casinos, we are throwing away a competitive advantage over Dubai and Qatar.


     But nearer home, Thailand will have a casino.  Prime Minister Thaksin told that to a leading Singapore banker who told me.  The world is moving on.  It is a wide open world.  Do we want to be left behind?


     The third reason why I support the integrated resort with casino is that gambling in all its forms is already easily available in and near Singapore.  The table games of the casino are not available in Singapore but Singaporeans have easy access to them on cruise ships sailing out of Singapore and in nearby Batam Island.  In other words, easy access means that casinos are already here in Singapore even though they are not physically here in Singapore.


     Lastly, I believe that having casinos in the integrated resorts will not dramatically increase the social costs of gambling.  I am not brushing aside the social costs, which are real and a price we have to pay.  But we should look at the incremental social costs, not the total social costs, and balance them against the economic benefits and social problems of unemployment.

 

     I am aware of the social costs.  Recently when I was in London, I met a New Zealander who is working for Nestle.  He is married to a Singaporean who is a friend of my daughter.  He asked me about our proposed casino.  I explained why we were considering it.  I then asked him for his views.  He was against it.  He explained

Column:337

that he was posted to Sydney many years ago.  He lived near the Crown Casino.  There was almost a suicide every week in the casino car park.  He was against the casino because of the high social and human costs.  If we could do without the casino, it was better to do without it, so he advised me.

 

     Two of my friends just came back from Las Vegas.  They are professionals.  They went with some Singaporean high-rollers, and these are really high-rollers who roll something like $1-2 million a night, to enjoy the perks provided by the casino for high-rollers.  My friends played golf in Shadow Creek.  It is a most exclusive course reserved only for high-rollers and their friends.  The golf course is built into the desert, and is one of the most beautiful golf courses in the world.  They had good food.  They enjoyed the top class entertainment.  Yes, they also gambled and won a tidy sum of money.  I asked them what advice would they give me regarding our casino.  This was before we had decided on going ahead with the casino.  To my astonishment, they advised me against it.  Their main worry is that a casino will undermine our work ethics.  In Las Vegas, money talks.  Everyone is chasing after money the easy way.


     I am relating these personal anecdotes to illustrate the point that there are no easy answers, one way or another.  There are social and human costs in proceeding with the integrated resorts with casinos.  But assuming that we do not proceed, does that mean we will have no social problems?  I do not believe so.  We have been remaking the Singapore economy to stay ahead.  The integrated resort proposal is a key component of our overall strategy.  If we cannot keep our economy vibrant and create enough jobs for Singaporeans, what is there to stop the better educated Singaporeans from migrating?  Those who cannot leave will be 

Column:338

stuck here.  Singapore will stagnate.  If that happens, what will be the fate of our sons and daughters?  Do they have to work overseas as guest workers, and work under difficult conditions?

     The dilemma we face is similar to Britain's.  I sat next to Mrs Tessa Jowell, Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport, at dinner when I was in London for the Singapore Season in March.  She is the Minister in charge of the mega casino project amongst other duties.  Like us, she agonised over the same issues.  She and the Labour Government had come to the same conclusion that Britain had no choice but to go for integrated resorts with casinos.  They already have casinos, but these are small casinos in hotels.  So they have decided that they must go for mega resorts with casinos to generate growth in the tourism sector.  I asked her about the social costs.  She said that they had to manage them.  For example, casinos operate for 24 hours in artificial light.  Gamblers, therefore, lose track of time.  She was thinking of requiring casinos to have skylight so that gamblers could tell night from day.  I do not know whether this will help, but the point is we must think of all ways to minimise and manage the social costs. 


     I am now no longer the Prime Minister.  PM Lee is the man in the hot seat.  As Cabinet was divided on the issue, I told him that the burden of the decision rested on his shoulders.  If the majority was against going ahead with the integrated resorts, he should go with the majority.  But if the majority was for going ahead, he should not simply follow them.  He had to weigh the views of those who object carefully against the economic benefits.  But whichever way he decided, we would support him.  The PM has decided.  As he told you on Monday, he is the one who has to ultimately carry the burden of the decision.


Column: 339

     The Government's decision affects the lives of all Singaporeans and the future of our country.  Nobody can say that we have made the right decision or not until years later when we have the benefit of perfect hindsight.  But having made the decision to have the integrated resorts with casinos, we must now focus on minimising the social costs, while maximising the economic benefits.  It is within our power to make sure that the decision turns out right.  And the people who can play a bigger role here are exactly those who object to the casino.  They must help us minimise the social costs of our decision, taken after long and hard deliberations, in the best interest of our country.

 

     We have had an open and passionate public debate.  On an issue like this which engages very deeply our personal values, there can be no unanimity of views.  I welcome the strong stand taken by those who opposed the casino idea.  These Singaporeans give Singapore its moral ballast.  If there were little objection to the casino, I would be even more worried.  For it would mean that we have become so blase about life and have lost our moral bearing.  I do believe that we can manage the social costs of the two casinos, otherwise I would not have supported the project.  Our family, social and religious institutions are strong.  Have faith in the judgment of the Government and the strength of Singaporeans.

Column:340

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Is the Senior Minister saying that the Cabinet was somewhat caught after the request for concept plans and they have to proceed because these people had spent so much money on the concept plans and, if not, the international reputation of Singapore would be affected?  That is what I thought he said just now.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: That was what I said.  But that is not necessarily the Cabinet's view.  That was one of the reasons why I thought we should go ahead with the next stage.  It was my personal view.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, for allowing me to participate in this debate.  Before I proceed, I just want to say that I do not understand Minister Lim's point just now about the Workers Party and Mr Low Thia Khiang politicising the whole issue.  He said he is not criticising Mr Low but then he spent the next 25 minutes criticising the Workers Party and Mr Low Thia Khiang.  If that is not politicising the whole issue, then what is it about?

 

     Sir, the big decision had been made.  Singapore is going ahead with two casinos.  To borrow Minister Lim Hng Kiang's illustration about cooking porridge which was also mentioned in this debate, what I and many Singaporeans are interested to know is this:  will they get a share of this cooked porridge - "nang ming wu hoong bor"?

 

     Although the SDA is morally against the idea of having a casino in Singapore, I do not want to repeat and belabour the many strong arguments brought up by the anti-casino supporters in this House.  The decision to cook the porridge has been made, so let us move forward towards ensuring that the maximum number of Singaporeans will benefit from this

Column:341

project, possibly at the expense of some addicted gamblers and their families, and we will try to keep the number of "sacrificial lambs" down.

 

     Sir, the focus of my speech today will be on three main points.  One, the safeguards against addiction, increased crime and suicides.  Two, the economic benefits accrued from the casino going to Singaporeans and Singapore society.  Three, and my last point, now that the additional vice of the casino has come into Singapore, where do we go from here?

 

     Sir, as some Members have spoken quite correctly, 18th April is a sad day for many anti-casino Singaporeans.  They had worked and argued hard in the hope that their moral, social and health arguments will persuade the Government from setting up a casino in Singapore.  It seems certain to many anti-casinoians that all calls to debate are all hogwash - a big PR exercise.  At the end of the day, the Government will always proceed with whatever decision it had made, all in the argument that it will ultimately benefit Singapore.

 

     Sir, the argument "that it will ultimately benefit Singapore" is a very deceptively  attractive argument.  How can any sensible Singaporean object to any initiatives that the Government says "will ultimately benefit Singapore"?  How can anyone answer to MM Lee's question "can we afford not to" persuasively?  Either these people are not sensible, or they will be construed as religious people or high moralists. 

 

     But, Sir, could it also be that these people see beyond the arguments put forward by the pro-casino camp as deceptive?  As the Prime Minister had rightly pointed it out, their concern is not about economic advantage.  Rather, it is

Column:342

about stopping the gambling vice from taking root in Singapore.  It is about preventing people from getting addicted to a Government-sanctioned vice.  It is about preventing a rise in organised and petty crimes in our society due to the gambling addiction.  It is also about preventing family breakdowns and suicides due to problem gambling.  In short, it is about the preservation of our society as we know and hold dear to.

 

     Now that the vice of gambling is going to be introduced here, the people have every right to question how effective can we expect the additional measures and safeguards announced by the Government on 18th April to prevent gambling addiction, increased crime and suicides will be.  More importantly, we want to be assured that none of our friends, family members and loved ones will ever become addicted to gambling, resulting in bankruptcy, crimes and/or even suicide, like Simon Lee's case.  Thanks, but no thanks to the casino, integrated or not, whatever.

 

     Sir, consider that at present, even without a casino, the police are already having real big problems dealing with and eradicating the illegal loan-shark syndicates and the problems it creates among the cash-strapped.  With a casino, it will only get from bad to worse.  Higher penalty and installing CCTV at the innocent victims' premises will not make the problems go away.  What more can the Government do to eradicate this problem?  More police action will also not make the problem go away if there is huge money to be made.

The problem is in the demand, and a casino in our little island will definitely drive up demand.

 

     Consider also how people get addicted to cigarette smoking, alcohol drinking and the consumption of recreational drugs.  It always gets socially started innocently among friends having fun.  But, over time, months or even years, the neural pathways in our brains get more established

Column:343

and a bigger, stronger dosage is needed.  Before he knows it, the person becomes addicted. It is the same for recreational gambling. It takes a person of great will power and determination not to fall into addiction and to get out of it if he does.  The problems and damage it caused are tremendous to the suffering addict and his or her family.

 

     Sir, I like gambling, and I know I would be easily tempted to go to the casino to gamble when it is set up.  But, Sir, I also know that the Government has no legal and moral rights to introduce temptation for other innocent people to fall into these addictions - be it gambling or drugs.  Flee from temptation.  Nobody can fight temptation.  Teach a cat not to be tempted by a fish, or a drug addict not to be tempted by the substance in front of him?  It is not possible.  You are addicted, you would want to.

 

     But since the Government has decided to officially sanction gambling in the IR proposal, I want to ask the Government: how will public education, counselling and support services, medical treatment, research and the setting up of a National Council on Gambling ever help to prevent weak-willed people from getting addicted to gambling in the first place?

 

     These are helps given to people after they have become addicted, not before.  It will not help to prevent people from falling into addiction, or suffering financial loss due to a game of chance.  And if addicted persons go for gambling treatment and counselling - and they are always financially strapped severely - will it be totally and completely free?  The Government and its service providers have no legal or moral right to charge even one cent for the rehabilitative services provided by the IMH or the counselling service providers.  This is because the problems of addiction are a direct consequence of the temptation endorsed by the Government.  Also, will the future Government be sued in the

Column:344

distant future for bringing in the temptation in the first place?

 

     As for suicides, it greatly troubled me that the Government knows full well that the suicide figures will shoot up after the casino is set up and it will level off after a few years.  This means that we should expect more people jumping off buildings or onto on-coming MRT trains to commit suicides.  Yet, the Government still refuses to put up glass barriers at open platform MRT tracks to prevent all these possible suicides, citing cost.

 

     The Government seems prepared to sacrifice some citizens in pursuit of its economic objectives, but not bear the cost of installing these physical and costly safeguards.  I hereby demand that a lot more resources be channelled to social service providers - those that provide counselling and suicide prevention services.  Social workers are the worst paid lot among the professionals.  This is most regrettable.

 

     The Government must increase its compensation structure to attract and retain good qualified social workers, just like how it increased the allowance of MPs to attract more people to come into politics.  These social work professionals provide an important essential counselling service to help our society, especially so after the casino is being set up, because there is going to be increased demand for its service.  So, we need to pay good price to attract these professionals to come in to provide these essential services.

 

     Also, I propose a compensation fund to be set up to compensate and care for the dependent family members of gambling victims.  The dependants of gambling victims, especially if it is a gambling suicide case, cannot be left to fend for themselves after their primary care providers fall into addiction and/or crime.

 

     Next, the Government must also compensate Singaporeans and Singapore

Column:345

society from the accrued economic benefits gained from the casino resort - for the expected rise in crime and social ills.  It must increase its social expenditure and greatly subsidise the essential services - like healthcare and transport, just to name a few - from the rise in the GDP and revenue collections expected.

 

     As I said in the Committee of Supply debate, the Government must also look into relaxing the tax burden on the people and business further.  The additional economic push and revenue collected from the casino resort and tourist receipts must not be reasons for the Government to increase its budget on the other Ministries and salaries.  For that matter, Ministers and senior civil servants should be penalised for becoming complacent in the booming years of the early 90s, and failing to introduce key initiatives that will help promote tourism competitiveness to Singapore.  We have grown complacent and ignored the importance of the tourist industry until high unemployment sets in, and the carpet is pulled from under our feet.  Where is the helicopter vision that is so often touted of our Ministers?

 

     Now that it is going ahead with the casino IR project, the Government should allow and encourage an investment fund to be set up by interested Singaporeans to co-invest a substantial stake in this casino project.  We should not let the big foreign players have 100% ownership of this casino project.  As the Chinese saying goes: "fei shui bo liu wai ren tian".  It is important that part of the profits of the venture be earned by Singaporeans.  As we all know, Singapore is the ATM of the East.  So, why should it all go to the foreign investors when raising cash for viable investments is never a problem in our affluent Singapore?

 

     Lastly, now that there is an additional vice coming to Singapore, what is next? 

Column:346

Where do we go from here?  Will there be no other bigger and better integrated casino resorts sprouting up around Asia in the not-too-distant future?  I do not think so.  As Minister Mentor had said yesterday, whatever Singapore does, many other countries will follow.  If we do not, they may not. But, if we do, they will do.  Our intention to get into this vice trade will serve to persuade our neighbours to do likewise.  Otherwise, how can they catch up?

 

     So, if the competition gets too intense and our casino project becomes less viable, and the Singapore society becomes more acceptable to the ills of gambling, will future Government then relax its social restrictions on Singaporeans to go there for a punt?

 

     If China - our main tourist target group - gets into problem or imposes travel restrictions for its citizens to get into the casino here, then what is the Government going to do about it?  Allow Singaporeans easier access too?  When the two casinos are operating, what will happen to NTUC, SAFRA and all the country clubs' gaming machines and their jackpot rooms?  They will not have enough profits to sustain their operation.  Will they also ask and demand for the roulette and baccarat tables too?

 

     Lastly, are there any more creative wholesome ideas being considered for the future growth of Singapore, after the casino?  How about having a world-class F1 racing circuit to bring in the tourists too?  Or a Jurassic Park?  In short, Sir, start thinking and exploring the next big exciting project for Singapore now before we get complacent again and get caught in the next big economic downturn with our pants down - like now.  Tourism market share drops from 23% to 13% from 1993 to 2002.  Whose fault is that?

 

     To conclude, Sir, the controversial decision has been made.  Plans are now

Column:347

under way to call for tenders.  Whether we personally agree or not to the idea, it is time to move forward.  The Government can really do a lot more to alleviate the fears and anxieties of the socially concerned by putting more money and resources to address these social concerns.  We must always be prepared and willing to explore other helpful ideas and initiatives that seek to preserve the work ethos of our society.

 

     More importantly, Sir, there is no room for complacency and sitting on our laurels, like the Government had done in the thriving 90s.  Profits can go up, revenues must go up, but cost and asset enhancement schemes must never be allowed to escalate out of hand in our new economic environment.  Do not overplay the political agenda at the expense of our economic prosperity.

Member, Mr Steve Chia, had mentioned earlier.  May I ask Mr Chia whether he supports or does not support the IRs after all that he had mentioned in his long speech?  Does he support the need to create 35,000 jobs, and also the need to enhance the livelihood of Singaporeans?  He asked whether there was enough rice (muai)  for our fellow Singaporeans to be shared.  I do not know if Mr Chia was in the House when the Minister for Trade and Industry talked about the economic benefits of the IRs and the potential contribution to our GDP - I think $1.5 billion - the revenues and the taxes.  Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, Mr Lim Hng Kiang had elaborated on the economic benefits and I will leave Mr Chia to read that speech once again, and also PM's opening speech.

 

     He was talking about share of taxes and all that.  We have already heard the

Column:348

Ministers mention that our long-range objective is to keep our taxes down, and this is a stream of revenue.  And talking about jobs,  I could not understand Mr Chia's point just now.  Also, he talked about whether the money was to be used for counsellors and family service centres.  If Mr Chia was in the House and was awake, when Minister Vivian Balakrishnan was talking about the social exclusions and social safeguards when the IR is in place, it was very clear that he also mentioned that the levy collected would be channelled to the Tote Board, and the Tote Board would also contribute to all these organisations that will take care of gambling addiction and the social ills.  Later, Minister Khaw Boon Wan had also talked about that.
