and the kind of society we want to have.  I think that thus far, the Government has shown that, in its decision to go ahead with the two IRs, the Government has not thrown caution to the wind for economic gains in respect of the ills that Government has already recognised and it has come up with plans to take care of them.  It has taken Singapore many years of careful and well-timed decisions to get to where we are today.  In my opinion, if the costs of the IR are deemed to be too high, we can still survive without it, but how well, that is another question.  Mr Chia seemed to mention all these problems and ills will come about if the casino or IR fails.  But he forgets that we have other engines of the economy.  It is precisely because we

Column:349

have the other engines of the economy that we need to augment.  We have been talking about the manufacturing sector which may not produce many more jobs and we are squeezing that.  We are pushing ahead with our biomedical hub and education hub.  So this is not the only engine. The IR is not the end-all and the be-all solution. 

 

     An IR, however, presents many opportunities for Singapore.  Having considered the advantages and costs, I am convinced that the IR is indeed timely.  We have from time to time talked about the Singapore brand.  If you talk to branding specialists, they will tell you that a brand needs to adapt and change its image to keep its current users and entice potential users.  This is an opportunity for us to augment, to update if you will, the Singapore brand. If we hesitate too long on a decision to develop an IR, the rest of the region will pass us by and overtake us.  We will be no more than a little red dot, boring and sleepy.  Regional competition from Hong Kong, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand are all considering IRs.  I understand from a Hong Kong friend who said that Hong Kong had to bend their knees for the Disneyland project.  Can we afford to opt out, hold fast to our principles against the ills of gambling, while Singaporeans and tourists travel elsewhere to exciting IRs set up in the region?  Will Singaporean values be threatened and the society, as we know it, disintegrate if an IR is set up?

 

     I was brought up by strict parents by adhering to certain traditional values - work hard, respect your peers and elders, contribute to the community, and make an honest living.  I remember when I was young, like Mr Lim Boon Heng had mentioned, I played the game of "tikam-tikam".  I used to run around Swatow Street, Bugis Street, Hylam Street at North Bridge Road - I think we called it Tong Lam in Cantonese - and I played

Column:350

"tikam-tikam" at the street stall.  Some of you will recall this game.  It was a game of chance.  I picked a number, and if you are lucky, you win a prize.  Anyway, I won a package of chocolates that looked like a package of cigarettes. 

 

     However, having won the prize, I went back to my maternal grandfather's home, my father was there and I had,  I would call it, public caning actually, the biggest shelling by my father and I thought to myself the next day that the cane marks were permanent. Aside from the chocolate package that looked like cigarettes, the game of "tikam-tikam", although seemingly harmless fun, was in fact gambling.  This was what got me into trouble with my folks.  To my parents, gambling was a big no-no.  They frowned upon it and did not want me to think it was okay, even if the stakes were low.  So, since young, I did not care much about card games.  Gambling to me is a non-event.  It does not give me a rush.  I am probably one of the few Cantonese I know who do not know how to play mahjong. 

 

     I am also very curious at this point when Mr Chia declared that he liked gambling, how he keeps good control.  Perhaps, when the gambling addiction organisation or body is set up, maybe Mr Chia could share a few of his controlling techniques.  Even so, I am in support of setting up an IR in Singapore.  I came to this conclusion simply because the decision to sit out this opportunity and do nothing will hamper our continued development as a country.  The IR would have iconic status in keeping with Singapore's vision to be one of the great cosmopolitan cities in the world.  It would present to the world that Singapore is still at the pinnacle of many things, like our much vaunted public housing, CPF and ERP system.  We have been at the forefront with many firsts.  Our short journey from independence to first world was no fluke, it was pure determination and true grit.  Internationally, that is our image.

 

Column:351

     How do we see ourselves then?  We have strict but fair laws, we have had many firsts among the world in how we do things. Again, I mention the ERP, chewing gum ban and perhaps even secretly proud that these "firsts" by Singapore have been considered or emulated in whole or in part by other more developed nations.

 

     In this competition for the tourist dollar, no one will be remembered for being second place. I think recently we hear that the Hong Kong International Airport was voted Most Friendly Airport and Changi Airport came in No. 2.  These are warning bells already.  At the same time, Singaporeans will declare that our social mores  have matured, and we are not a staid backwater, but a confident, vibrant and forward looking society.

 

     We are in a position to become the jewel (or as MM has called yesterday the "Gem of Asia"), an eclectic mix of business and entertainment.  With an increase in Chinese tourists, up to 56% in 2004 over 2003, and others from Japan, Hong Kong, Europe and US, we can expect a spillover in hotel, F&B, airline, transportation, retail, MICE industries, 10,000 jobs directly related to the two IRs when it starts operating.

 

     Singaporeans have voiced valid concerns regarding the ills of the IRs.  I urge them to reflect on the record and style of this Government.  At no time in our past has the Singapore Government embarked on a decision with similarly far-reaching consequences without weighing the costs and benefits carefully.  For a country like Singapore, we learnt early on that we need to be nimble and to constantly seek or create options and examine and implement them carefully, and later finetune.

 

     The inclusion of a casino as part of an integrated resort will not mean we become a cowboy town where suddenly an explosion of vice, money laundering

Column:352

and gambling addiction will be the order of the day.

 

     As a financial centre, we have come thus far as a choice among global wealth managers as a booking centre.  Top-tier banks want to service their customers from Singapore.  We know that the Government is committed to the push towards establishing ourselves as a pre-eminent financial centre.  It is unimaginable that a responsible government will give up this engine of the economy or let the image be tarnished.

 

     On the banking aspects, specifically, the money laundering guidelines put in place and the regulatory supervision in all aspects of money laundering are strict, though even-handed.  Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure Mr Chia will agree with me being formerly a member in the financial industry.  He only knows too well that the money laundering guidelines are very strict and the banks are very serious about this.  This makes banks, wanting to operate and continue to operate in Singapore, put anti-money laundering a priority along with running a profitable franchise. 

 

     On drug enforcement, we have shown, and we are known, to be tough on drug trafficking and drug abuse.  While we have been at the brunt of some human rights activists due to our harsh laws, we have been steadfast to our core values and recent reports by CNB have shown just how successful we are.  Regional and international drug enforcement agencies sit up when we are mentioned.

 

     At a recent conference on drug enforcement that I attended with fellow hon. Member Mr Ahmad Khalis in Laos, some member countries were eager to learn and apply our laws. But they were also very quick to point out that even as they want to apply our laws, Singapore has put in place concrete strategies to reduce both drug demand and supply of

Column:353

narcotics.  This says a lot of how we do things in Singapore.  Passing a law is only part of it, as we have the system and complementary strategies to remove the scourge of drug abuse and opportunities for trafficking.  The law comes in then to enforce and deter such acts.

 

     We have thus shown how the Government's process and perspective is in tackling problems of such nature that can strike at the very social fabric of  our life of Singapore.  Therefore, the ability for such resorts to operate and maintain its reputation under strict laws will in fact count towards brownie points for such companies to set up operations elsewhere.  They come in here fully aware of the kind of regulatory compliances to adhere to.

 

     To me, the potential ills of an IR can be averted through careful planning and execution.  However, at the moment, I think the Government has to acknowledge there are some challenges before it.  Firstly, many Singaporeans are not convinced that the multiplier effect or spillover benefits mentioned will have a direct impact on them.  Singaporeans have been told in broad and general terms that the IR will have many economic benefits, for instance, jobs will be created through the IR development and the tourism industry will receive a boost.  However,  they get the feeling that many of the concerns about the casino arise because Singaporeans do not fully understand as yet the full scope of the development within the IR apart from the hotly debated casino.

 

    Secondly, if jobs are to be created, then my unemployed residents have asked me what kind of jobs will there be, and how many will there be for them.  They want to know how they can get those jobs so that they can climb out of unemployment.  Our Government may wish to convey to Singaporeans how the

Column:354

job creation related to IR will address our unemployment problem.  How will these jobs trickle down to our unemployed?  Whether specific training programmes will be developed so that those who are interested may re-skill themselves through appropriate training?  I think we have a four-year lead time for that.

 

    Mr Lim Boon Heng had already spoken on this, maybe MOM in time will also share with us their strategy on how we can prepare 10,000 people for these 10,000 jobs as well as the 25,000 downstream jobs.

 

     Lastly, in Minister Balakrishnan's statement on Monday, we were reassured by his mention of the various safeguards to be put in place.  However, the Government can do more to set Singaporeans at ease by detailing and providing the specifics on these safeguards, such as what are the processes required by a family member to exclude one from the casino.  Looking at the profile of the problem gambler, his family members may not be savvy or resourceful enough to utilise the "exclusion" provision.  I felt that the statement was perhaps at this time short on details that could otherwise give Singaporeans a better grasp of the safeguards to be put in place.  Some other questions could be: what does the implementation time-line look like for the various help groups to be set up and staffed?  Where do you begin with all these good and well-intentioned education programmes on gambling addiction?  How relevant will $100 per day or $2,000 per year be in the year 2009?  Will the Government then stipulate a fixed review period for such a levy? 

 

      I hope the Government can elaborate on these.  But I understand that it is still early time. This will help dispel some anxiety and hence allow Singaporeans to better understand the Government's proposed measures towards countervailing the social ills envisioned. 

 

Column:355

     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in conclusion, I would like to share with Members an article I read in the April issue of MacWorld, a magazine dedicated to Apple computer users.  It is an article I thought could be quite related to our talk and debate on the IR.  Steve Jobs explained the success of Apple in an interview.  When Adobe refused Apple's request to jointly develop a consumer video editing software for Mac, Apple had to go at it alone.  That resulted in Apple starting the Applications Software Division that now boasts a thousand engineers that resulted in its hugely successful i-Tunes software.  Singaporeans who use MP3 players would be very familiar with this.  Steve Jobs said that he "felt like a dope" for not moving quicker.  Back in 2000, he was so distracted by perfecting video editing on the Mac that he did not notice that people were using computers and CD burners to make audio CDs and downloading MP3s from illegal online services, such as Napster.  Jobs was quoted as saying, "I thought we had missed it.  We had to work hard to catch up."  Fortune reporter Brent Schlender wrote that, "Yes, even Steve Jobs, the technological visionary of his generation, occasionally gets caught looking the wrong way."

 

      Singapore cannot afford to look the wrong way or even not look at how the IR could place us in the global village.  We look the wrong way and someone will come along and clobber us out of the running.  Staying on top, staying attractive for visitors, vying for attention and consideration for investment dollars is all competition.  In any competition, I believe we compete to win.  Sir, I think Singaporeans need to compete with others for the IR.  We have been early adopters and must continue to be early adopters.  I am confident that Singapore's confidence in the values that we have been instilled will pass on and preserve

the kind of society we have come to be so proud of.  I am confident that an able Government that has put high on its agenda since

Column:356

independence of hard work, honesty and integrity while building our nation will preserve these same values with the IRs on our island state.

     Sir, Mr Chiam See Tong spoke in the House - unfortunately, I was not in, but I heard the discussion outside and read about it in the media - and he said that 40 years of PAP virtues were flushed down the drain in one fell swoop.  He implied that the PAP changed direction for the sake of changing.  The question here is whether did we change for the better, or we turned our backs on principles.

 

     Sir, Einstein is one of the most brilliant minds of the 20th century.  He changed his mind many times.  When confronted by a brilliant scientist in a conference, Einstein answered, "I change my mind when the facts change.  What would you do?"  Professor Stephen Hawking is one of the most brilliant minds living today.  He is the Professor of Theoretical Physics in Cambridge.  He did not win a Nobel Prize,

Column:358

but that is because Nobel Prizes for Physics are not awarded for Theoretical Physics.  Sometime in the 1980s, he wrote a book called A Moment in Time.  He postulated many theories.  One of the theories was that the black hole in the universe is so dense that nothing ever passes through it.  Even gravity cannot flow through it.  Recently, Stephen Hawking, still alive and brilliant as ever, said he was wrong.  Gravity might be able to pass through it.  Two brilliant minds, cleverer than most of us here, in fact maybe all of us combined, whose minds expand the universe, changed their minds because, when the facts change, they change. 

 

     Deng Xiaoping is my hero.  He survived three ups and three downs.  In his late 70s and close to the 80s, he made a momentous shift.  He started this gai ge kai fang.  Basically, he was shaking loose the chains of communism, at a great risk, because at his age at late 70s, he could just cruise and be honoured by the communist system, but he did not.  He took another risk.  His comrades asked him.  Millions of Chinese had died for the cause of communism.  It was capitalism that threw China into darkness for 200 years.  And before that, China was a shining light.  The West overtook China because of corruption and capitalism.  In the Long March, where Deng Xiaoping followed with Mao Zedong, millions of gallons of blood were drained down the valleys.  Deng Xiaoping told them that "Communism, as we know it, did not work for China."  Millions starved.  In the Cultural Revolution alone, in the wen ge period, it was estimated that 30 million Chinese died of starvation, something that communism promised to overcome.  It did not.  And Deng Xiaoping told his comrades, and later we knew it through his books, he said, "If we open the windows, the flies will come in.  If we shut the windows, we will suffocate and die.  With the flies, we can survive.  They will be a nuisance.  Some of us may suffer from

Column:359

diseases, some might die.  Without opening the windows, we will all die." 

 

     When the economic conditions change, politicians must change.  A politician's job is to look after the people's welfare.  It is to give them jobs when they have no jobs.  It is to look after their welfare when they cannot make ends meet.  Today, in Singapore, in spite of the low unemployment statistics, it is still too high for us.  It is too high historically because we have never crossed 2% unemployment for a long time until the last few years.  Too high for us because we really have no welfare, other than HDB public housing.  Many of us, in our weekly MPS - and tonight is my MPS, after this I will have to go - we are confronted with people who come to us, young and old, asking us for jobs. 

 

     I remember this guy.  He was into jail for petty theft for six months.  He came out, he could not get into his rental flat because he owed arrears, so HDB did not allow him in.  He owed Singapore Power money because he did not pay his bills.  He could not get in.  Out from jail, without a home, he could not get a job.  What did he do before?  He was a driver.  But we know that every unemployed person today tries to be a hawker, driver or taxi driver.  There are just not that many people to take taxis or to be driven around.  There are not that many people to frequent F&B outlets.  So, you see taxi drivers sitting around, working longer hours trying to make ends meet.  We owe a responsibility to these people who are unemployed to give them gainful employment.  Every time I give him an NTUC voucher, he took it, but he told me, "I want a job.  I do not want NTUC vouchers."  These are young people.  He is a young man.  I write to the Ministry.  The Ministry tried placement positions.  But there are just not enough placements. 

 

     In this House, we have heard many arguments about the worth of retraining. 

Column:360

Many MPs have a valid point.  You ask our retrenched workers to go for retraining.  Will there be jobs at the end of the retraining?  It is a valid question.  If you ask 100 workers to go for retraining, to be IT-competent, but you only have 30 jobs waiting for them, 70 people will still be unemployed.  I have no answers.  We need to grow the economy.  Have we reached a cul-de-sac, a dead end?  I think not.  There are many options for us.  We can fire all the other engines - life sciences, banking, education - and we must never exclude an integrated resort. 

 

     I heard Irene Ng saying that Chinese are compulsive gamblers.  It has always been said.  And Chinese tend to believe that.  It was also said that gambling is wired into the Chinese DNA, so there is nothing you can do.  Many eminent Ministers here have said that they have gambled a few hands but they are not addicted gamblers, they are just casual players.  But we are humans.  We control our genes.  Recently I saw a National Geographic documentary programme.  The geneticists said that the genes, the DNAs, make up our physical person and control us.  But in the case of human being, our brains control the DNA.  There is a saying in life sciences that we, as humans, can ask the DNA to go jump in the lake.  I think we must not succumb to the belief that Chinese are compulsive gamblers and that there is nothing we can do.  Yes, Chinese are more prone to gambling, and this is a fact in every society where Chinese exist.  But in Singapore, I think the Chinese live under a benevolent Government that is, I am sure under the MCYS Minister's guidance, determined to minimise the impact of social gambling. 

 

     And I think we must measure the success of these IRs, as Mr Lim Swee Say mentioned, not just by the economic gains, but also by how much social damage we can contain.  I am a scientist.  So, if we have more gambling avenues, the social impact must go up.  It is not

Column:361

likely to go down.  But it will not disappear without the IRs.  Our challenge for the Minister for MCYS is actually to ask him to account for the number of pathological gamblers year after year after the IRs have opened their doors.  Today, without the IRs, we have something like 55,000 addictive, problem and pathological gamblers.  Ask him to account for the numbers in 2009, 2010, and measure the success of our IRs and weigh it against the economic gains. 

 

     I believe that this Government can contain the social impact and make the IRs, together with the casino component, a kind of IR with these Singapore Government or PAP Government characteristics, just like Deng Xiaoping was able to fashion capitalism with socialist characteristics.  If we look at China today, it is still a communist country.  But in a way, it is very capitalist.  Billions of Chinese have been lifted from poverty within a short space of 20 years.  Deng Xiaoping took the correct course of action.  History today has vindicated him.  In the case of Singapore, I think the decision to go ahead with the IR will also vindicate us.  Time will tell.  But I think this Prime Minister is determined to succeed. 

 

     For a long time, we have believed that Singapore fetches a premium, that people will come to us because we are an efficient place to do business.  We are.  There is law and order.  If you do business, you might want to come to Singapore, because things get done, laws are transparent, rules are enforced.  But if you are on holiday, if you are a tourist, you need not come to Singapore.  You can bypass Singapore.  Jet travel has diminished the problem of time and space.  It is only a matter of cost.  Budget travel means the death of cost.  Today, with budget travel, you can go anywhere at a fraction of what it used to be.  This means that more people will bypass Singapore, if

Column:362

there is no reason to make Singapore an end destination or an important transit stop.  In the past, when I was a student in Australia in the early 1970s, whenever Australians want to go to Europe, they would stop in Singapore and shop, because we were a shopping paradise.  Today, Australians do not.  They may transit, because Qantas, SIA and British Airways stop by and they will stay in the transit lounge. 

 

     Not because we are not a shopping haven; we are.  Branded goods in Singapore are still among the cheapest.  If you read the International Herald Tribune, there is always an arbitrage section where they highlight, say, a particular electronic product and say how much it costs in Hong Kong, Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, etc, and Singapore is always among the cheapest place to buy that particular product.  But the differential in price between Singapore and the most expensive is really quite marginal.  So you do not come to Singapore to buy a particular product, nor even by the way, because that product is on the Internet.  At the click of the button, you get instant gratification.  So what do they come to Singapore for?  Not much actually.  All 5-star hotels are the same, whether it is in Inner Mongolia, Dubai, Auckland or Santiago.  They all look the same.  If you check into a Sheraton, they look the same.  If I blindfold you and fly you round the world and put you back into Singapore, you will think you are in Santiago. 

 

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang said that we must make the IR a place where tourists will regret not coming here.  I believe it is something that we should aim for.  Many years ago, when I was still teaching in the university, a few of us, together with one MP who is still in this House today,

decided to invest in Kuala Lumpur in an apartment.  At a time where Singapore was saying, "let us go north and invest there", the growth triangle strategy. 

 

Column:363

     It was the worst investment of our lives. The capital value of the property in Kuala Lumpur tanked 30%-40%, even by today's standard.  We bought it in the 1980s.  The ringgit value fell 30%.  Together, we have lost quite a fortune.  Had I put the same money in the 1980s in Singapore, even with the housing downturn from 1997 to now, we would be much better off.

 

    For a long time, we did not go to Kuala Lumpur. The apartments we had were gathering dust. We were just paying property taxes and the management fees. So we decided, since we could not sell, we might as well go and use the property.  In the last few years, my family went up to stay together and we found KL a completely different place. What you can get in Singapore today, you can get in Kuala Lumpur, at half the price because of the ringgit exchange.

 

     With their octopus-like network of highways, KL is now a very accessible city, very friendly.  The Kuala Lumpur City Centre (KLCC) is really quite a piece of marvel.  Those of you who have been to KLCC would know that from the KLCC, it just takes a 40-minute sprint to Genting on the uphill run.  On the downhill run, because there are fewer cars and you can travel at higher speeds, it takes only 30 minutes. There is a non-stop highway that links KLCC to Genting Highlands.  It is remarkable, and the highway is the best in Malaysia, four lanes on each side with very safe barriers.

The weather is excellent and the pricing is a fraction of what you might pay anywhere else, including Downtown East.

 

Column:364

      But Genting is a success and many people benefit from Genting for short holidays. Those who do not gamble benefit a lot because the facilities are reasonably priced.  In fact, I would say very cheap and it is very good value for money.

 

     If we can copy Genting's formula, but upgrade it many notches up, Singapore, as an end-destination or an important transit stop, will go up many notches.  It will benefit many Singapore families to have reasonably priced entertainment. Today, Singaporeans travel overseas for entertainment. There is a huge loss of revenue for us.  If we can plough back some of those losses, I think we are all better off.  We can do many more things. 

 

     We have heard of suicide problems and families in distress through gambling.  That is true.  I personally know a few.  But I am sure we also know of families who run into problems because of unemployment.  Newspapers highlighted some cases of people jumping down because they could not feed the family, not because of gambling.   If we can strike a balance between helping those who are jobless or those who are unemployed by giving them higher value-added jobs and containing the social fallout, I think this integrated resort idea is worth pursuing.  If we were to pursue the idea, we should do it well.

PROPOSAL TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED RESORTS

     Debate resumed.

     Mr Lawrence Leow Chin Hin (Nominated Member): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I speak in support of the Government's decision to proceed with the two Integrated Resorts (IRs).

 

     From a business standpoint, there is no reason to object to the two IR projects as they are expected to bring in a total investment of $5 billion, create some 35,000 jobs and fuel the growth of the tourism industry with spin-offs for the other business sectors.

 

     The economic benefits are substantial.  Our economy, particularly the tourism and related sectors like retail and F&B, is in need of a booster. And now, it will come in the form of the IRs.  SMEs in these  sectors will benefit from the impetus and new opportunities the IRs will bring.

 

     As an economy that is not well-endowed with natural resources, we have to work extra hard to stay competitive and attractive.  The IR projects will certainly help to enhance our attractiveness as a business and tourist hub in this region.

     While there have been a lot of concerns expressed in respect of the social ills that may accompany the casinos in these IRs, which I would acknowledge are valid concerns, we must trust that the Government

Column:369

would put in place measures to tackle these potential problems.  Apart from a proven track record of making sound decisions, our Government is also known to be prudent and conservative in its governance.  If one were to consider the fact that even chewing gum has been banned here, it must really mean something for the Government to want to allow casinos in Singapore.

 

     I would say it is a decision which is easier to make against than for, and it is a decision that has been made for, and for the long-term good of Singapore.  It is a decision that places greater emphasis on the long-term economic outlook over the potential social cost that may arise out of the casinos, and rightly so.  After all, a frail economy would bring about many other forms of social problems.  Hence, focusing on building a strong economy has always to be a priority. 

 

     I am convinced that the Government would put in place appropriate measures and safeguards to minimise and contain the negative social impact of the casinos.  Besides, the casinos are only part of the IRs and there would be entertainment and leisure facilities in these resorts to enrich the social lives and recreational experience of Singaporeans.  In this regard, the IRs would also have some positive contribution to the social lives of Singaporean families and that, to a certain extent, would help to mitigate the negative social impact of the casinos.

 

     Sir, I am, therefore, pleased that the Government is proceeding with the IRs.

     Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I support the decision to proceed with the two integrated resorts.

 

     We are moving fast into a new and different era.  Singapore cannot continue to do what it had been doing.  This does

Column:370

not mean that we have to discard what we have, but we must be prepared to review our position, to modify, add and subtract where necessary.  In the process, that differences will arise among our people will be inevitable, but we must not allow this to paralyse nor divide us as a nation.  We should look at an issue holistically, evaluating its pros and cons, and rationally make the decision based on the overall long-term interests of Singapore.  This, I believe, is and should be the basis of the IR decision and all other decisions.

 

     Ever since the idea of an integrated resort was recently raised, each group has looked at it from its own perspective.  Those against it have focused on the anti-social aspects of the gaming component, while those for it have focused on the economic benefits.  On Monday, the Prime Minister had brought the various threads together, providing a holistic picture of the issue and explaining the Government's decision.  I am sure that with this exposition, many more Singaporeans are able to reconcile their differences.

 

     Sir, I am persuaded by the merits of the projects.  Let me recall what resonates most when the Prime Minister spoke on Monday.

 

     The world has changed.  Our uniqueness has been eroded.  We cannot remain as we were without losing our competitiveness.  The integrated resort is part of our overall strategy to stay relevant in this new world.  It is only a part, but it is an important part.  Furthermore, the gaming portion, the casino, though critical to the success of the IR, is itself a very small part physically, not more than 3-5% of the total physical area. 

 

     One of the most persuasive arguments is that the projects are supported by renowned international companies that see the tourism potential in the region, and are prepared to invest $4-5 billion of

Column:371

their own money, without any subsidy from the Government.  This is a lot of money and reflects the seriousness that they took of the IRs. 

 

     If Singapore rejects the projects, they will build them somewhere nearby.  In a globalised world, with easy low cost travel, more people will travel and Singaporeans who want to gamble will find their way there.  Hence, we will still be confronted with the problems associated with gambling, but without the ability to manage the problems and benefiting from the other beneficial aspects of the integrated resorts, such as, with more travellers coming through Changi airport, the latter will consolidate and confirm its hub status and SIA will find further growth.

 

     The integrated resorts will add buzz to the city.  They will not only do this, but I believe that they will initiate a mindset change among Singaporeans, a renaissance that will arouse and create buzz for the whole of Singapore.  It will set up a chain reaction that will permeate the buzz throughout the system.  I am confident that it will open up Singapore in both the physical and abstract sense, and will be seen to be so in the eyes of both Singaporeans and the world.  I am also confident that Singapore will become a much nicer place to live as a result of this decision.  We will have new infrastructure, facilities, events and activities to enjoy, things that we would not have without the integrated resorts.  For example, through the involvement of the international companies, we will have quality international shows on our doorsteps.  As an MP, I have been privileged to see the various submissions, and like my fellow MPs, I believe that the infrastructure will be iconic and will transform our skyline and add buzz to the city. 

 

     The IRs will create many jobs, ones that our less-skilled people can do.  On

Column:372

many late MPS nights, many of my residents have waited to see me, to seek my help to find jobs.  They are overwhelmed with debts and arrears, worries about where their next meals will come from, embarrassment of being reminded of debts by their relatives, or worse, harassment by loan-sharks, the inconvenience of having the utility supplies disconnected, sadness by their inability to give pocket money to their children, to send their children to school, family quarrels and problems, just to name a few.  These social problems, the sense of hopelessness, the desperation, the despair, are probably similar, and as bad as those faced by compulsive gamblers.  They said, "Give me financial help, but better still, give me a job."  Many were working in factories that had relocated.  But output from the manufacturing sector has not shrunk.  New manufacturing jobs are being created, but these are out of their reach.  Only the well-educated need to apply.  I believe that the service sector, especially the tourism sector, will be a good employer for many of our less-skilled.  The integrated resort will be an important driver of our tourism sector.  A tourist who comes to the resort uses not only the services of the resort but will visit other parts of Singapore, shop, travel, etc.  Many jobs will be created for Singaporeans as a result of the integrated resorts.

 

     Sir, the social ills associated with gambling are serious and we must not trivialise them.  Personally, I am concerned about the anti-social effects of gambling, but given the tremendous benefits that the resorts promised, could we have rejected the IR projects especially when we could take steps to minimise their downside?  With the decision to proceed, have those who opposed the integrated resorts lost their arguments?  I say not.  If you ask them whether they agree with the economic benefits, I am sure that to a man, or woman, the answer is "yes".  But they see the social ills as over-riding to

Column:373

their opposition to the projects.  I personally do not have interest in gambling and I am aware of the associated social problems.  But it is an activity that will not go away.  To most, it is merely a form of entertainment.  It is not in itself a bad activity as long as participants do not allow themselves to be carried away by it.  Like most things, excesses are bad.  I am thus happy with the strong measures that the Government has incorporated into the IRs to contain the ill effects.  This development has also strengthened my support for the projects.  This is where I give credit to those who spoke out against the casino.  I am sure that their strong advocacy against the ills of gambling has strengthened the measures and efforts that have been put in place to contain the adverse effects of gambling on our people.  For this, the anti-camp has made their presence felt and we should thank them for voicing strongly their concerns.

 

     Sir, like my fellow MPs, the response by our people to the IR projects has made me very proud of them.  We have shown the world that we are not the docile and passionless people that we were made out to be.  We have shown that when it comes to issues and matters that are important to us, we can and will make our voices heard.  On this issue, both the pro- and anti-sides have their own good reasons for the stands that they took.  In deciding the matter, the Government has taken both views and made a decision that takes into account both of them and is in the overall and long-term interest of Singapore.  In so doing, both sides have their positions acknowledged, though not entirely addressed, but to the extent possible.  Let us accept the decision, close rank as a people, unite and move on to tackle many other issues that still await and confront us.

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, this morning, as I was driving my two

Column:374

younger children to school, my 15-year old son remarked, "So mum, we are going to have two gambling dens!"  To which my 11-year old daughter added, "Yes, one at Sentosa and the other at Marina!".

 

     Sir, I was somewhat taken aback by these remarks, but regaining my composure, I went on to explain that, "No, we are not having two gambling dens, but two integrated resorts, each with a casino component."

 

     I told them that put simply, if we do not allow the casino component, then they cannot look forward to having theme parks, like Universal Studios, right at our doorstep.  Singaporeans would have less business and fewer jobs.  But, "As children, mummy and daddy will not allow you to visit the casino, and even when you grow up and are allowed into the casino, you should avoid gambling as far as possible."

 

     Sir, my children understand what casinos are.  Last December, I brought them to Disneyland in Anaheim and Universal Studies in LA.  Then, as I had wanted to have a look at Las Vegas to better understand the type of IRs we are considering, I also brought them to Las Vegas.

 

     When we were there, we did not gamble.  We visited the shops.  We went to the games arcade at New York, New York and Circus Circus.  The children liked the newer IRs, like Bellagio and Venetian, as they were very grand and beautifully designed, with spectacular water features and great shopping and eating outlets.  But

Column:375

they did not like the casinos, with the slot machines and gaming tables, which were literally just right behind most of the hotel lobbies, and which they often had to walk through to get to the other facilities.  Many of the casinos were also smoke-filled, because smoking was allowed.  The negatives outweighed the excitement, and because of that, my children told me that they did not like Las Vegas, and given a choice, would not want to go there again for a holiday.

 

     Sir, children could be a little confused by this - unable to reconcile what we preach about the ills of gambling and the fact that we will be having casinos on our own shores.

 

     Sir, this is also likely to be one of the key arguments of many anti-casino lobbyists like Mr Fong Hoe Fang, the pioneer of Facts (Families Against the Casino Threat in Singapore).  Sir, for them it is not just about the destructive effects of compulsive gambling, but also the moral imperative of our value systems.  As Mr Fong noted to the press, "We say one thing and do another.  We tell our children gambling is bad, but how are we to answer them when they ask why a casino is allowed in Singapore?"

 

     Sir, I empathise with Mr Fong, and many others like him, as these are genuine concerns and cannot be trivialised.  Sir, now that we have decided to go ahead with the IRs with a casino component, we should, among others, kick-start our public education campaign right away.

 

     The public education campaigns launched must be intensive and should at least start from the upper primaries.  It should highlight the social ills of gambling and inculcate positive work attitudes.  It should target particularly our young, help them understand why we need to allow casinos on our shores, even though we preach against gambling and its ill effects.  Besides the schools, parents and religious leaders must, of course, also be involved to reinforce the values we want to inculcate in Singaporeans.

 

     Sir, Mr Fong and some others have expressed the sentiment that they do not think their views have made a difference.  Sir, to Mr Fong and others like him, I want to say that I believe they are mistaken and

Column:376

I want to thank them for their efforts.  I think that if it were not for their passionate voices, we might not have had such a comprehensive set of social safeguards and multi-pronged approach laid out by no less than three Ministries to address problem gambling.

 

     The Minister for MCYS has pledged that MCYS will enforce the social safeguards strictly and will not compromise on these safeguards at any point in time,

just to improve the economic viability of the casinos.  The Health Minister has called upon the IMH to start beefing up its capabilities and expertise to deal with problem gambling and to benchmark itself against the best treatment centres in the world.  The Minister for Home Affairs has also pledged that he will do everything possible to minimise any negative impact which may arise from the integrated resorts with casinos. 

 

     Hence, I want to say to Mr Fong and others like him, that they should not lose heart, their views do matter a great deal and the missionary zeal they have shown over this issue is a positive sign of a maturing citizenry and civil society that cares for Singapore's future, and wants to play a part in shaping public policies.  Active citizens like them could continue to play a role in the future as watchdog on our value systems when other equally difficult and emotive issues arise.

 

     Sir, like many others, I also abhor the whole idea of gambling on both moral principles and religious grounds.  I have never gambled at casinos, not even at the one-arm bandits or one-finger muggers, as they are aptly called.  I view sitting at the jackpot machine a waste of precious time and cannot see how one can get thrilled over what is almost a certain prospect of losing one's hard earned money in the casinos!

 

    There is a wise Chinese saying which goes "shi du jiu shu", ie, gamble 10 times

Column:377

lose nine times.  In fact, I would even venture to say "shi du quan shu", ie, gamble 10 times lose all the time, since, as we learn from Chia Teck Leng, the house always wins.

 

     Even though MCYS' recent survey shows the incidence of pathological gambling to be 2.1%, which is comparable to those in Hong Kong and Macau, this is still 2.1% too high.  Having casinos on our own soil would conceivably lead to an increase in this percentage, although no one can be sure of the extent of any such increase.  But, Sir, having been a real estate professional in my previous incarnation, I am also fully aware that for some time now, both the Government and the private sector are looking at ways to attract more tourists, but they have largely been unsuccessful.

 

     When I was a lecturer at NUS, I used to be in charge of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' training scheme for government officials from developing countries, including China.  That was in the late 1990s. Even back then, the Chinese officials would tell me that they came to Singapore to learn about our tax systems, our public housing programme, and so on.  But when all the official business was over, they would go to Bangkok, Pattaya and Genting to have fun.  They told me that Bangkok, and not Singapore, is a shopping paradise as the goods in Singapore are too expensive.  I believe what was true 10 years ago is more true - if there is such a phrase - now.  Hence, we have lost our edge as a shopping paradise.
 

    In year 2000, I was involved in a study to evaluate the level of interest of local and foreign developers in developing iconic urban entertainment centres in Singapore that will help to draw visitors and add buzz to the entertainment scene.  Urban entertainment centres (or UECs)

Column:378

may be said to be a precursor of the large scale integrated resorts we are currently considering.  Even in year 2000, the urban entertainment industry was still relatively new but rapidly evolving.

 

     The response to our survey done in conjunction with a US counterpart was at best lukewarm, with only a handful of local and foreign developers, who said that they may consider developing such a project.  Their main concerns were, as expected, our high land cost, as well as whether such a project could draw the overseas crowds to make it viable, since the local market catchment is too small.  Even reducing the length of the land lease from 99 years to 60 years or 30 years did not significantly improve the financial viability of the project.

 

     I have also been involved in several other projects where potential overseas and local investors have looked at developing large scale theme parks but, without exception, all have concluded that it would be difficult to make such projects viable, without heavy state subsidies. All these projects, of course, did not have a casino component.  It would therefore be difficult to attract investors to develop such large scale integrated projects that require substantial capital commitments to the tune of billions of dollars, if their risks are not mitigated in part by the potential revenue from having a casino component.
 

    The integrated resorts with casinos are clearly not the panacea to all our woes.  However, I think it is like the icing to an otherwise plain looking but well baked cake, to make it that much more enticing for tourists, investors and foreign talent alike.

 

     The integrated resorts will enhance our efforts that we have made to restructure the economy, such as increasing our focus on the financial services and logistics sector and attempting to improve the tourism sector.  Hence, whilst I am

Column:379

against gambling and the casino per se, I understand that if we want to reclaim some of the tourism pie, create new jobs, boost our economy, and stay in the competition, we would have to go ahead with the IRs incorporating a casino component.
 

    So, would having casinos detract from the value of Singapore's brand name as a safe, reliable, well-run country, with a high standard of morality and work ethic, which this Government itself has spent the last 40 years building?

 

     Sir, I believe that having the two IRs with casinos is unlikely to be seen to signal that we have abandoned our virtues of a clean and efficient government, a well-run and well-ordered country.  Indeed, having made the decision to proceed, rather than tarnishing the brand capital that is Singapore, the signal we should be sending out is that the best and safest place in the world to have a casino is right here.  In fact, Singapore's reputation for a clean government and strict regulation is what makes it so attractive to large IR companies looking for expansion in Asia.  Furthermore, far from creating a dent in Singapore's image, most analysts expect this move to go a long way towards changing Singapore's image as a sterile environment into a more "with it" happening place, sufficiently alluring to the talent and capital of the world.

 

     Personally, Sir, I am glad we had rejected the casino idea when it was first brought up in 1985, as back then we would likely have ended up with, what my son would call, a gambling den, if we had allowed a casino then.  Because IRs of the scale that we are considering now have not been conceptualised at that point in time.
 

    Again, speaking based on my experience as a real estate professional, I support the Government's decision to have two IRs, instead of one.  Whilst I do

Column:380

not believe that the social costs would necessarily double with two casinos, from a real estate point of view, I think the benefits which the two IRs together can provide are likely to be greater than the sum of the parts.

 

     Sentosa badly needs an iconic IR project with theme parks, spectacular waterfront and exciting architecture, which can give it the enchantment and the "wow" factor it needs, to put it back on the list of "must see" attractions, and make it a popular repeat destination for both tourists and locals.

 

     The Marina Bayfront IR, on the other hand, with its mix of convention, retail, food and beverage outlets, entertainment facilities and so on, would quite nicely complement and, indeed, enrich the existing mega developments in the areas such as Suntec City, Marina Square, the Esplanade, as well as future developments in the new Downtown, the Marina Barrage and the second Botanical Gardens.  The IR should give the whole area a boost and will act as the catalyst for the development of the entire area, including the massive BFC project.

 

     Having seen some of the proposals submitted for the two sites, I must say that I am thrilled by a number of the proposals which exhibit truly creative and visionary architectural designs and concepts.  These proposals should result in iconic developments displaying great architecture, which many experts and laymen alike have often lamented Singapore sorely lacks and needs.  In fact, at one recent dialogue I had with students from the NUS, a student actually lamented that our landscape and our architecture are boring.  He said that even the Durian is not enough.


     Sir, the economic benefits of the IRs, as estimated by the Government, are immense.  However, careful execution of

Column:381

the IRs is needed if these envisioned benefits are to be realised, otherwise our vision may just become one big headache!  The Government will need to apply the same meticulous and methodical approach it has used to arrive at the casino gaming decision to the evaluation of the request for proposals.

 

     I would urge that the evaluation panel for the subsequent detailed proposals insists on one of a kind concepts, sensitive to our urban setting and tropical climate, instead of a replica of other projects elsewhere, however grandiose.  This would then truly make the IRs "Uniquely Singapore".  Apart from the design and design expertise, the evaluation panel should also focus on the business sustainability and the track record of continuous innovation to keep the crowds coming back.


     Sir, to deal with the concern that the IRs might not be able to adequately draw a large enough foreign clientele, I urge that in the next step of the evaluation and selection process, attention should be paid to detailed analysis of the business case put forward by the bidders - their projections and how they propose to draw the foreign clientele and visitors needed for the casino and the IR.
 

    It is imperative that the IR operators have the international marketing prowess to pull in the tourists, upon which the success of the IRs hinges.  Otherwise, the IRs would merely be cannibalising existing businesses.

 

     The condition that no more than 50% of the revenue should come from gaming operations (otherwise there will be a hefty surcharge) as well as the fact that the IRs are wholly private sector investments (ie, zero subsidies from the state) are good, as they should spur the IR operators to work hard to attract foreign clientele.  The

Column:382

STB should work together with the IR operators both before and after the opening of these projects to market the IRs overseas and attract the tourists.  Both can derive synergies by pooling their resources to market the projects and Singapore.
 

    Finally, Sir, there is worry that a large proportion of the 35,000 new jobs created might go to foreigners, as even now there appears to be many foreigners working in the hotels, F&B and other retail outlets.  The first comment one of my grassroots made when the IR announcement was made on Monday was, "Can we make sure that more of our locals would bag the 35,000 new jobs created?"

 

     Sir, as Singaporeans could suffer from some of the incremental social costs, the Government has the duty to ensure that Singaporeans will benefit most from the economic gains, including the jobs created.  MOM, through WDA, NTUC and the CDCs, and perhaps even the IR operators when the IRs are awarded, could work together to design and provide skills training for the jobs which will be created by the IRs.  This will help to ensure that there will be a ready pool of local workers to take up the jobs offered by the IRs.
  

   Sir, I also fully support the call by my parliamentary colleague, Mr Gan Kim Yong, as well as Straits Times journalist Ong Soh Chin for us to ensure that Singaporeans will be able to provide world class service commensurate with the world class architecture and entertainment we will be developing.

 

     We must change the mindsets and attitudes of Singaporeans towards the service industry and equip them with the skills necessary for them to provide high quality world class service in the retail, leisure and entertainment industry.  In fact, just as we would need to benchmark our

Column:383

containment measures against the best in the world, and do even better, we must also benchmark our IR operations and the services we provide against the best in the world and strive to top them, to create compelling success stories, like what we have done in the case of SIA.

 

     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in many ways, the economic imperative compels us to take such a decision on the IRs.  I support the decision to go ahead with the IRs, but with adequate safeguards to deal with the social fallout.  Of course, the decision can be construed by moral purists as sacrificing long-cherished values at the altar of mammon.  But that is really putting it too starkly and simplistically.  If mammon can be had, and its demons held at bay, why not?  Hence, the key to the political success of the two IRs lies, in my view, in the containment measures to minimise the social ill consequences.
 

    The decision to proceed is only the beginning of a major calculated game - pardon the pun - we have taken for the long term economic well-being of the nation.  Like all bets, no one can be sure if this will turn out well in the long run, although the odds seem to be in the favour of this decision now.  Much work needs to be done to enhance the chance of success, maximise the benefits and minimise the costs, which should not be trivialised.
 

    Although this decision is not a unanimous one, my sense is that if put to a national referendum, the ayes will outnumber the nays.  Whatever our stand, ultimately, we are collectively responsible for the long term good of Singapore and, hence, I urge all Singaporeans to work together with the Government to make this succeed, both economically and socially, now that the decision has been taken.  This is a calculated gamble which we can scarcely afford to lose.

 

     Sir, I support the decision.
